scenes.location: A NATIVE VILLAGE IN A CLEARING BETWEEN THE JUNGLE AN
characters: ROSE FROM HIS POINT OF VIEW
THE STEEL CYLINDERS IN BOTTOM OF BOAT
SHOOTING FORWARD ALONG PORT SIDE OF BOAT
FROM THE INSIDE EDGE OF THE PORCH
A SHOT ALONG THEIR RAGGED LINE --
METHODICALLY AS SHE WOULD PULL OUT A NEW STOP, ROSE SWIPE
ALONG THE FULL LENGTH OF THE BOAT
THE PROPELLER SHAFT OF THE LAUNCH
THE LENGTH OF THE BLEAK CHAPE
A DIFFERENT PART OF THE RIVER
HORRIBLE CENTIPEDE-LIKE CREATURE SLITHERS INTO VIEW BETWE
SAME AS THAT WHICH OPENS THE PICTURE --
THE MOVING, THINNING OVERHEAD TANGLE OF
FROM OTHER SIDE OF THE RIVER
PAST THE CONGREGATION, ON BROTHER, AT THE LECTERN, AND RO
HALF-WAY THROUGH THE FOREGOING LINE, AN EXOTIC
TWO OF THE ORGAN KEYS. WITHOUT INTERRUPTING HER PLAYING,

dialogues.speaker: A CHAPEL
dialogues.text: Intense light and heat, a stifling silence. Then the SOUN of a reedy organ, of two voices which make the words dist and of miscellaneous shy, muffled, dragging voices, begin a hymn:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) "Guide me O Thou Great Jehovah..."

dialogues.speaker: AT THE ORGAN
dialogues.text: BROTHER, a missionary, faces CAMERA near center; ROSE, hi sister, is at side, her face averted. Everybody is singin "Pilgrim through this barren land..."

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER
dialogues.text: middle-aged, rock-featured, bald, sweating painfully, ver much in earnest. He is very watchful of his flock. He sin as loud as he can, rather nasally, and tries to drive the meaning of each word home as if it were a nail. He is bea with his hand, and trying hard to whip up the dragging te "I am weak, but Thou art mighty..."

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: early thirties, tight-featured and tight-haired, very hot but sweating less than Brother. She is pumping the pedals vigorously, spreading with her  knees the wings of wood which control the loudness, utili various stops for expressiveness of special phrases, and  rather desperately studying the open hymnal, just managin to play the right notes -- a very busy woman. She, too, i singing her best and loudest, an innocent, arid, reedy  soprano; and she, too, is very attentive to the meanings words: "Hold me with Thy powerful hand."

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: completes "Thy Powerful Hand"; o.s. Voices of singers.  Unperturbed, Rose finishes her casual disposal of the bug and pulls out a new stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through rest of hymn, SHOOT and CUT against its lines for meaning, irony and pathos, roughly as follows: FULL VIEW of congregation past Brother and Rose. They are all Negroes and nearly all are dressed in glaring white - the women in garments like camisoles, the men in pants wh reach about to their shins: splayed, bare feet. Some of t faces bear the marks of heavy savage ornaments which have been removed, or of tatooing and scarring rituals which h been outlived -- torn nostrils, lips and ear lobes, a nec curiously thin and weak from the enormously heavy metal b which used to surround it. Some of the children are naked near-naked. Nearly everybody dutifully shares open hymnal but it is obvious that few, if any, can read. The singing most of them is weirdly shy and inchoate -- a little like that of a neighborhood audience when a group "sing" is im upon them. But on certain high phrases a glad, rich, wet  soprano lifts out large and happy, very child-like; and a big male voice bleats forth joyous, jazz-like improvement on the tune, a little off-key. There are very few men pre We detail or bring into salience, bare feet slapping time and an anklet shimmying; a very earnest young married cou with the wedding ring prominent and an impressive phalanx children in tow; the owner of the happy soprano, a sweet, contented, pre-moral face; the owner of the big male voic the inevitable rather effeminate man in every congregatio who loves religion because he loves Beauty. He is immense pleased that he knows all the words (the others just dab them): he sings them without any knowledge of their meani they sound Hawaiian. Also, we SPOT a tremendously old,  wrinkled, bent-over woman, dressed in white like a good  Christian, but with a bone stuck through the septum of he nose. She croaks, toothless, bleary-eyed. These things must be disposed of by late in the first sta which continues: "Open now the crystal fountain Whence the living waters f Let the fiery, cloudy pillar Lead me all my journey throu We close on the old dame with the bone singing -- "...my journey through." o.s., on "...fiery, cloudy pilla a queer SOUND, steadily louder: the absurdly flatulent,  yammering syncopation of a rachitic steam motor. Eyes beg to wander from hymnals: CUT IN Brother frowning and singi harder trying to impose order; attention to the hymn begi to fall apart a little; FOLLOW the white, veering eyes to FRAME, through the open window.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: whose WHISTLE lets out a steamy whinny, then REPEATS it,  with great self-satisfaction. She is squat, flat-bottomed thirty feet long. A tattered awning roofs in six feet of stern. Amidships stand her boiler and engine. A stumpy fu reaches up a little higher than the awning.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He is in worn, rather befouled white clothes. He is baref and his feet are cocked up and he is sitting on his shoul blades, smoking a bad cigar. He wears a ratty boater,  slantwise, against the sunlight. He is attended by two yo Negroes so tall, thin and gracile they suggest black maca One is proudly and busily puttering at the engine, which  requires a lot of attention: the other is fanning ALLNUTT who is feeling just fine. Allnutt speaks to the fanner in Swahili. The young man without breaking the rhythm of his fanning, licks out one long, boneless arm and alters the  lashed tiller; the Queen begins to swerve toward shore. o the hymn continues, all but drowned by motor noise.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHAPEL
dialogues.text: Rose pulls out all the stops, spreads her knees, and pump like mad in her effort to drown out the ENGINE SOUND. Bro sweats and sings even harder, scowling, shaking his head. The singing is fraying out half to hell; the congregation a solid black wall of wandering eyes; a few pious convert frown or nudge at the less pious; a little group is coale toward the window. The hymn, meanwhile, continues: "Feed me with the heavenly manna in this barren wildernes Be my sword, my shield, my banner, be the Lord my  righteousness." Rose's sense of artistic propriety is too much for her. T keep things going, she ought to play loud, but on the nex line -- "When I tread the verge of Jordan..." she shuts down to t vox humana and the tremolo and maintains that through -- "Bid my anxious fears subside." On this line, Allnutt appears and lounges against the fro door frame still drawing on his cigar. Rose lets everythi rip fortissimo on the closing lines: "Death of death, and hell's destruction land me safe on  Canaan's side." By the time of "hell's destruction," Allnutt becomes awar that a lighted cigar in church is bad manners, and, noddi casual apology to Brother, tosses it away onto the packed dirt, out of our sight. Instantly there is a hell of a  hullaballoo o.s., all in gibberish, against which the clo words of the hymn compete stridently. The less self-controlled of the flock are no longer singi and are craning their necks and rolling their eyes, but w just enough Sunday-Schoolish discipline to stay in their  places. The more pious, with effort, keep their eyes wher they belong and SING all the harder. IN QUICK SHOTS, Brot and Rose redouble their efforts. There is a final long-dr "Aaaa-men," and it is clear this is the closing hymn of t service. Brother closes his book and picks up his service book; Rose shuts and locks the box-organ and puts the key (which is on two shoestrings) around her neck. Brother st with decorous alacrity down the middle aisle. Immediately following him, the natives hurry from their benches.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING PAST ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: on the cause of the hullaballoo -- a squabbling football  scrimmage of virtually nude male heathens, battling for t cigar butt. In b.g., if permissible, a couple of equally  nude women; a thin, pot-bellied little boy dashing happil toward the fight. Brother and the eager heads of white-cl Christians come into the SHOT, BACK TO CAMERA, watching. of the heathen fights his way up from the heap with a yow of supremacy, filed teeth in a great grin, prancing and  holding high above them all the frantically busted cigar vaudeville; others leap after it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt, seeing the wrecked cigar, looks kind of bleak. A Brother comes out, he meets his annoyed eye with mingled  reproach, apology and indifference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brother) Hello, Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your mail. Sorry I'm late,  but one thing and another kept me in  Limbasi. You know how it is, Reverend. (he winks) Or maybe you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gave me a real going over when  I got to the mine. They called me  all the names they could think of --  in Belgian, but I don't mind so much  bein' cursed in a foreign language,  so I just took it with a smile. They  wouldn't fire me, I was sure of that.  There ain't nobody in Central Africa  but yours truly knows how to get up  a head of steam on The African Queen.  It may sound like bragging, Reverend,  but I'm mighty close to being in-di- spensable. Seein's how them Belgians  is too damn cheap to buy 'er a new  engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose joins them at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferently) Good morning, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin', Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose's prayer book is clamped under her sharp elbow. Her  walking is used to country, yet tight and spinsterish.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT, BROTHER AND ROSE
dialogues.text: For a moment Allnutt looks at Rose with utter casualness indifference; his eyes leave her even before Brother spea Brother is looking through the mail. Past them, the liber Christians walk into the sunshine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, splendid, At last they've come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My marrow seed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind these lines, the TINY OLD WOMAN with the nose-bone makes herself prominent; she's waiting to speak to Brothe almost plucking his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Allnutt) Yes. (to Grandma) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in snaggle-toothed,  adoring enthusiasm) Oh Mistah Sayuh, I does like how you  preach!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'k you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All dat hell-fish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother nods and smiles uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De way yo' neck swell up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in dismissal) Thank you, thank you. (to Allnutt, without  enthusiasm) You'll stop for tea, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't care if I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking TOWARDS AND PAST CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM TABLE
dialogues.text: Rose at dead center, Brother at her left, in profile, All at her right, opposite Brother, in profile. The room is s shaded against heat it is gloomy. The silence, gloom and  heat are stifling. Rose is pouring the second of three cu of tea; she pours the third. Brother is deep in the news a Mission paper. Allnutt sits oppressed by the silence, l a child on his good behavior. A long silence while Rose  leisurely pours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take sugar, Mr. Allnutt, I seem  to remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Miss. Couple  o'spoonfuls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doles them into his cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose passes him his tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bread and butter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking some) 'oh obliged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his cup an inch to drink and puts it down aga Nobody else is served yet. Rose fixes Brother's tea and p it beside him. She puts a slice of bread and butter on hi plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) 'k you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose finishes fixing her own tea, and helps herself to br and-butter. She lifts her cup, not quite crooking her pin and sips. Allnutt still doesn't move; he is waiting for  Brother. Brother finishes and turns his page, and, withou shifting his eyes, finds his tea with a blind hand and bl drinks it and sets down the cup again. Allnutt, licensed, takes a big bite of bread-and-butter and picks up his cup and washes it down. By Rose's covered reaction, it is cle that she has been taught never, never to do this, but tha she expects no better of such as Allnutt. Allnutt sighs w and contentedly. This, too, is bad manners to Rose, but s takes it in her stride. They go on soberly eating bread-and-butter and drinking t The only SOUNDS are those of china, sipping, chewing and  swallowing. Nobody looks at anyone else. Brother and Rose are wholly, stiffly reposeful; they are used to this. All begins to get a little squirmy, like a child in church. T silence makes him visibly uneasy, but he tries not to sho his uneasiness. All of a sudden, out of the silence, there is a SOUND lik mandolin string being plucked. At first the sound is  unidentifiable, though instantly all three glance sharply up, each at the other two, then away; in the next instant they recognize what it is and each glances sharply,  incredulously, at the other two -- and then again, quickl away; then Brother and Rose glance with full recognition Allnutt, at the instant that he knows the belly-growl is  his. At the moment of recognition, he glances down at his middle with a look of embarrassed reproach. He glances up quickly and slyly -- hopeful they've missed it -- to find the eyes of both still fixed on him. The instant their ey meet they bounce apart like billiard balls, and fix on th first neutral object they happen to hit. Then Allnutt loo at them again: neither will look at him. All three lift their cups at the same moment, for a cover disembarrassing drink of tea. Rose and Allnutt simultaneo recognize what they are doing (Brother is pretending to r misses it, and goes ahead and drinks his), and both, at t same moment, lower their cups to saucers with an almost  simultaneous clink. Both look away from each other. Broth clears his throat rather loudly and turns a page. Rose an Allnutt reach for their cups; Brother beats them to it. W Brother has again put down his cup, Rose -- the tail of h eye on Allnutt -- picks up her cup and drinks, her eyes  carefully empty above the cup. Allnutt has his cup again the way to his mouth when his insides give out with a gro so long-drawn and terrible that Rose first flinches, then makes a noise across it with her spoon, stirring her tea. Brother tightens up like a fist, his first reflex being t this loud one is a calculated piece of effrontery. Allnut just endures it, with a look of suffering stoicism. When is over there is a tense silence. Allnutt slowly, slyly l up at Brother; he is stone. He looks to Rose; she is gazi far off into space. Allnutt is quite embarrassed, and kno they are. He does his best to relieve his own embarrassme and theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a friendly, yet  detached tone) Just listen to that stomick of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a silence. By their almost invisible reaction, i is clear that to just listen to that stomick of his, is t last thing they want to do. Allnutt is a bit chilled by t silence, but he tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way it sounds, you'd think I'd got  an 'eye-ener inside me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence. Rose looks at Allnutt; their eyes meet; he attempts a fri smile. Her face goes stony with embarrassment and she loo quickly away. So does he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as soon as she can  manage it) Do have another cup of tea, Mr.  Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Miss, don't mind if I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes his cup, while she pours. There is a third grow not so bad. Allnutt says nothing. Then, after a pause:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks stone deaf. She hands him his cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much obliged, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks some tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queer thing, ain't it. (a silence) Wot I mean, wot d'you spose it is,  makes a man's stomick carry on like  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bread and butter, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes some and eats. After a little chewing, his jaws  slow; he is expecting another growl and listens intently; does Rose; none comes, After a little, Allnutt relaxes an Rose relaxes at least to a state of armed truce. They are both munching methodically, eyes out of focus, when Broth takes a curiously official-mannered gulp of tea, sets dow his cup, and breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbie Morton's a bishop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking the remark  is addressed to him) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt is pretty embarrassed to have said "huh."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely you remember Herbie Morton. (Rose looks doubtful) Blond, ruddy-complected chap, a bit  younger than me. He sang a solo at  the graduation exercises. "Holy,  Holy", I believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubiously) I think I remember. It was so long  ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's a bishop now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say Herbie was a bit younger  than I -- four or five years. (Rose pours more tea  into his cup) Surprising in a way. I mean -- well,  there was nothing outstanding about  him. He was no great shakes as a  student and he didn't have any more  than his share of the social graces. (a pause; he drinks  then eats bread and  butter, but with  rather less relish  than before) No doubt one does get ahead quicker  at home than in a foreign field...  And then, of course, he did marry  well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That manufacturer's widow. What was  his name? Briggs -- Griggs -- Briggs --  yes, Alfred Briggs. Soap flakes, I  think. Yes, Mrs. Alfred Briggs. (pause) Not to take anything away from Herbie. (pause) I am delighted for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was "Holy, Holy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence. Brother isn't even looking at his paper. Allnu stomach talks gently. They all accept it stoically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after quite a silence) There ain't a thing I can do about  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More tea, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Miss, I reckon not. About time I  shoved off, if I'm gonna get back to  the mine by tomorra night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insincerely) Don't hurry, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sure he is safe) Stay for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Thanks all the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother pushes back his chair. Allnutt pushes back his ch and gets up. Rose pats her lips with her handkerchief, pu back her chair, and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Allnutt brought the marrow seed  at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must say, though, they were forever  getting here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky they come through now, cause  it don't look like they'll be no  more mail for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon the Germans'll hold it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irate -- we sense a  background of  unpleasant relations  with the Germans) In heaven's name why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause it looks like there's a war  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Really? Where, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the patronizing  concern of one who  hears of another  Balkan brawl) Indeed! Between whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Germany, England, the whole --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (electrified) England!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pop-eyed) You mm -- you really mean war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wot they tell me. Germans claim the  British started it. British claim it  was the Germans. In any case, it's  war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great intensity) But what's happened! What do you  know about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a whip) Rose! (she shuts up fast) Exactly, Mr. Allnutt, what has  happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now, that's about all I can  remember. Oh yes -- France is in it,  too. She's with us, I fink. A lot 'o  them little countries are in it too --  Austria-Hungary, Spain, Belgium -- I  forget 'oo's with 'oom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet desperation) And that is all you can tell us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know. -- I'll try to pick up  some more, next trip to Limbasi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder to what extent we here shall  be affected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None, I shouldn't think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is German territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would they want to bother a poor  devil of a missionary and his maiden  sister? -- beggin' your pardons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are enemy aliens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wot's the difference -- in this God- forsaken place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bridling) God has not forgotten this place,  Mr. Allnutt -- as my brother's  presence here bears witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offence, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another puzzled pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like it... Well, I better shove  off now. Many thanks for the tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door and goes through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Brother and Rose come through after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, take care of yerselves. (he goes down the  steps) See ya next month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. And thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at bottom of steps) 'Bye, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: PAST THEM
dialogues.text: CAMERA watches them watch him as he shambles towards his  boat. He soon lights a stogie; his relief in smoking and being free of them is eloquent in his back. His boys jump action; curious villagers make way for him; the engine is going by the time he gets there. The boat backs out and s its course upstream; Allnutt turns and lifts a hand. Brot lifts a hand; Rose doesn't. The boat soon goes out of sig beyond trees. OVER the above, back-to-CAMERA, or quarter-profiled from rear as they idly watch his departure, Rose and Brother t quietly as follows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we perhaps call him back?  Get to Limbasi while we can?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with unction, yet  with dignity) The good shepherd does not forsake  his flock when wolves prowl. (a pause) Besides, I think Allnutt is very  probably right... I can't imagine  any reason why the Germans should  trouble us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I suppose not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now, the boat is pulling out; Brother and Allnutt exch their not very friendly waves. Rose looks idly after Alln in Sunday boredom. Nothing is said for a few seconds afte the boat vanishes; the SOUND of the engine dwindles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awed, and moved) War. England. Just think!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks, CAMERA STARTS a coldly SLOW PAN, past the  chapel, and square onto the jungle, so altering its posit behind Brother and Rose that they are held in -- l.s. (wh before they were in r.s.). (N.B.: BY MID-PAN the ENGINE SOUND dies.) An almost nude native explodes from the wall of jungle,  running as fast as he can, bellowing breathlessly in Swah and English. Until they hear his bellowing, Brother's and Rose's heads are still ANGLED AWAY from jungle -- not tow river still, but idle and unfocused. With the first sound his voice, their heads turn sharply, with weary impatienc not alarm, towards the sound. The native does not pause in the village, though he shout vague things in Swahili as he runs, setting up a kind of  helpless agitation among the villagers; in b.g. we see st more of them coming with lazy interest out of their huts, while the native tears towards the bungalow bellowing,  breathlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mistah Sayuh! Mistah Sayuh!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND BROTHER, (FROM RUNNER'S ANGLE)
dialogues.text: favoring Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Mistah! Oh Mistah Sayuh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes of Brother and Rose abruptly lift beyond the run and come into focus as hard as hawks; almost instantly, t faces become terrible with recognition, despair, and cour and, for the moment with uncertainty, still, whether such emotions are needed.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPS
dialogues.text: emerge from the somber wall of the jungle, tiny against t wall, but looking very efficacious and professional in th tropical uniforms. Instantly they form ranks before an of who barks an order in German, just audible to us. The nat are somewhat scared and awed, but mainly immobilized with scare, awe, and curiosity. Upon the order, the Germans  promptly break ranks and start swiftly and effectively ab their business. One group starts rounding up the natives. Another starts collecting live-stock, usable food and  supplies. Another covers operations with rifles. Two men  light torches and start setting fire to straw huts. One m stands by the officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; as soon as it  becomes clear what  the Germans are up  to, his voice is  quiet but harsh) Rose -- go indoors and stay there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o.s., the SOUND of their feet on the front steps. They co swiftly into the SHOT BELOW the CAMERA and walk fast, Ros trailing, towards the officer. After only a few steps Bro begins to trot, ungainly; Rose, still more ungainly, in h narrow skirt, trots too.

dialogues.speaker: THE OFFICER --
dialogues.text: a tired, rather heavy, neutral, thoroughly unmemorable fa He is not as tall as Brother, to whom he is giving the on over. His look is neither brutal nor humane: just experie It seems to say, roughly and humorously: "Well, well, wha have I got to deal with here?" His guardian soldier steps quickly to one side and forward; a nonentity with a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (boiling mad, the  innocent courage of  a lion) What is the meaning of this outrage!

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER --
dialogues.text: centered, but a little less close than before; his guard extreme r.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly, in German) Speak German, please; I speak no  English.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER
dialogues.text: the crest of a wave of righteous fury mounting just befor breaking; toppling forward; the terrifying face of a man  almost ready to murder out of a sense of being right.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOUR OF THEM --
dialogues.text: as close as the CAMERA can frame all four; as, simultaneo Brother lunges forward at the officer, Rose lunges forwar to prevent Brother; the officer steps neatly backward and sidewise, and his guardian steps forward briskly and, sha but just hard enough to be effective, and with an ugly SO of impact, strikes Brother on the left joint of the jaw w his rifle butt. Brother goes heavily to the ground with a groaning gasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rage, shock,  astonishment) No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at same instant,  squatting beside  him, turning his  head; she is beside  herself) Judkins!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP -- BROTHER -- (SHOOTING DOWN PAST ROSE) as she t his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (semi-conscious; his  jaw not broken but  bleeding and already  swelling) No. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across his words) Oh, Judkins. Brother dear. Come,  dear. Come, Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She helps him to his feet; past them, the officer and his guard walk briskly, aloofly away, and past the whole busi as Brother and Rose get up and the CAMERA LIFTS to normal eye level with them, a much later stage of the destructio of the village is visible in b.g. and is implied o.s. by  Brother's eyes. Brother's eyes, scorched-looking, appalled, all but demen flick from horror to horror; he is watching the annihilat of his life's work and, to his mind, the annihilation of  Christian and potential Christian souls; his head quavers the negative gesture like that of a paretic; his mouth, a hard up to this moment, trembles now and looks curiously  large and sensual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No, Lord! O no! O no! Lord! No!  O no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is in the SHOT with him; shorter and less favored th he is. Her eyes are constantly upon his face. Tears come of her eyes, but she is doing no vocal crying. She is wat his heart break and, essentially, she is watching him die and knows it.

dialogues.speaker: SAME AS THAT WHICH OPENS THE PICTURE --
dialogues.text: the hottest part of the day -- most smashing sunlight  possible. There is no village now -- only the round scorched marks  where the huts stood; a sketch of debris. At some distance from the bungalow, and in the middle of lot of gaping space, Brother is hoeing in his vegetable  garden. He is terribly small in the enormous barrenness a light. He hoes long enough to convey great loneliness and kind of blind perseverance, then straightens and looks ra vaguely around him, mopping his face and bald head with a handkerchief. Then, with an abrupt look of purpose, he st walking, letting the hoe fall where it happens to. He wal towards the bungalow, across the bare ground, not very fa or very steadily, but purposefully. The sunlight makes a  near-halation on his bare, bald head. The walk takes him  long enough to infer utter loneliness and the destruction any human sense of time. He starts up the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE IN THE PARLOR
dialogues.text: She hears him coming up the steps o.s. She continues mend his nightshirt. On SOUND of him coming through front door she glances up again and her face becomes curious, then  concerned.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER
dialogues.text: as he advances into room. He is dressed in his Sunday bes immaculate except for sweat-and-dust of immediate garden  work. His face is carefully shaven, but it has thinned an he is very pale. The wounded jaw is not bandaged and is  virtually healed; stubble around it. There is a streak of garden dust across the temple and up onto the bald head. is looking hard at Rose, but his eyes can't keep in focus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweat pouring from  him, teeth rattling) Why aren't you dressed, Rose? It's  time for Service.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: gets up, deep concern on her face, comes quickly to him,  bringing both into SHOT, and lays a hand against his fore Her reaction infers that Brother has a terribly high feve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must wear your hat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teeth chattering) Time, this minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose starts to lead and support his obstinacy, CAMERA WIT THEM, towards his bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must lie down a bit. You're not  at all well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resisting feebly but  coming along, shakily) But it's time. It's time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not well enough. Lie down a  bit, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should. I feel rather odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help you off with your things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a suddenly normal  and shriveling voice;  quietly) Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens his door for him; he starts through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he turns to shut  his door) 'k you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuts the door in her face. For a moment she stands outside the door as if paralyzed. Then she starts somewhere fast. CLOSE UP -- THEIR FORLORNLY POPULATED BOOKSHELF. Rose hurries into the SHOT and takes down a large obsoles looking Home-Medical Compodium.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: SHOOTING LOW across the bleak dining room table as she hu the big book to it and opens it. She is standing. She is  still in a painful rush through the index when o.s. there the NOISE of a catastrophic fall.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (BACK TO CAMERA)
dialogues.text: at Brother's door. By reflex, she hesitates and raps timi Instantly realizing the idiocy of this, she bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: inside Brother's bedroom, SHOOTING FROM LOW as she enters and stands a moment transfixed by what she sees, her face suddenly rigid and masklike with horror and pity.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN
dialogues.text: He is piteous, absurd and ugly; sprawled out on the floor ill-shaped as a wounded bat, with his nightshirt partly o shrouding his head, and his trousers half off, trammeling knees which are grotesquely angled. Between lowered pants and hiked-up nightshirt, a sad, humiliating expanse of lo white drawers in this furnace weather. His feet are foule up in his suspenders. The SHOT is to be both preposterous and shocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: past Brother from floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost whispering) Brother! Brother dear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes stooping towards him. CAMERA MOVES into CLOSE as she lifts his heavy head clearly into the SHOT and get it unveiled from the nightshirt. The big face looks ruine disgraced, dead, but a low mumbling sighing comes from hi He is far gone. She is about to try to lift him towards his bed when he b to walk; she waits and listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes shut; a faint,  delirious voice) Smite them, Lord! Smite the  Amalekites, hip and thigh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering -- almost  by reflex) Amen. (with a long a)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So cold and so foggy. My eyes are so  tired. Where is Rose? Rose, are you  down there in the shop? Rose, bring  me a cup of hot tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here with you, Brother dear.  Right here beside you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try to study -- so hard. I haven't  had the start some have: 'Ebrew;  Greek -- no -- facility. If only  there were more time. Well, if I  can't pass the examinations, I can  volunteer. I can be a missionary.  Rose, too. Not comely among maidens,  but she can become a servant in the  house of the Lord. Yes, even for  such as she, God finds a goodly use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is deep pain on Rose's face. She almost wants to sa something, but knows the senselessness of it. She just ke looking at him and listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with calm, resolve,  acceptance) I'm going to put my books away, Rose.  I'm not going to study any more. If  I don't pass, it only means that God  has other work for me. Thy will be  done. (in a different voice,  secret, piteous,  impassioned) But, Lord, if it be Thy Will, O let  me distinguish myself and give me a  call here in England, right here at  home, Lord. Mother will be so proud,  Lord. Abash and put to shame all  them that revile me and persecute me  for Thy Name's sake. (whispering; pleading) Lord, I have tried so hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is silent; she is motionless. Slowly LIFT CAMERA, losi Brother, CENTERING ROSE IN CLOSE UP.

dialogues.speaker: MUDDY WATER
dialogues.text: The screen is filled with a foamy, strongly sliding floor muddy water; a strong, serene freshness of water SOUND. T SHOT is VERTICAL onto this water from perhaps three feet  above it. o.s., already loud, and loudening, the NOISE of the engine of The African Queen. LIFT CAMERA, picking up the launch unexpectedly close as, slanting into broadside, she draws the letters of her nam

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: large across the SHOT. CONTINUE LIFTING; as boat passes, we see Allnutt very bri and see that he is alone.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: over SOUND of expiring engine and rattle of anchor chain, reacting to his first sight of the vanished village. He l a little scared and very cautious; he has seen what was d at the mine, and now even the smell of violence, or the e of its impact, makes him very uneasy. He is even dirtier more unshaven than when we first saw him and he looks  extremely tired.

dialogues.speaker: THE VILLAGE
dialogues.text: what we see of it from his angle. Since he is lower than village, all we can see is a lot of abnormal, empty sunli

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT, (SAME AS BEFORE)
dialogues.text: He is wary, but knows he must investigate. He goes oversi almost out of the SHOT, stepping across a stump to shore. SWING WITH HIM. As he reaches the top of the low bank, TRUCK with him, ME CLOSE, as he walks through a little of the burnt-out vill Past him, the scorched circular blotches where the huts w burned and half-burned little pens and fences; ravaged  gardens. He is still careful and uneasy. Unaware of it, h walks through this silence of devastation almost on tipto Now he raises his eyes towards the intact bungalow o.s., a new kind of carefulness comes into his eyes. STOP the TRUCKING and PAN with him as he walks past and b in the bungalow, looking cavernous, very still, and crypt or menacing in the sunlight, as he walks the last few pac towards it. He hesitates a moment at the foot of the step It obviously occurs to him that he may find corpses, or n at all. He starts up the steps, still walking a little  stealthily.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: through the screen door, from inside, as he comes up the  quietly creaking steps, sensitive to the mood of a kind o desolation different from that of the village; uneasy. He crosses the porch very quietly, again hesitates, peers th the gray screen door into the dark interior, and raps rat timidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., a dry quiet  voice with the calm  of exhaustion in it) Come in, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voice startles him as much as it should ourselves. He peers again, forehead wrinkled like a monkey's. He can't her. He shyly opens and comes through the door, mumbling  something apologetic and subversal. As he catches sight of her, SWING CAMERA to RIGHT, losing him, and PICK ROSE UP, MEDIUM CLOSE. She is past the angl of visibility from the screen door. She is in a wicker ro chair, sitting quite primly, working with those rings on  which embroidering is done. She glances up at him with ey like fused glass -- then quickly back to her needlework. is clear by the over-precision of her motions, and their  rigidity and tension, that she is under great strain, but this is to be keyed low and simple.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT, (FROM HER ANGLE)
dialogues.text: He watches her; he knows enough to keep quiet; he waits;  becomes aware of his muddy feet and quietly tries to clea one against the calf and shin of the other leg.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (SAME AS BEFORE)
dialogues.text: She does a couple more stitches, obtains sufficient contr of herself, and lowers the needlework into her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, as before) Thank God you've come.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT, (AS BEFORE)
dialogues.text: Nobody has ever thanked God in connection with him before His reaction is quiet, but clearly this is a surprising a novel experience. He says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.S.) Sit down, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind if I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks into:

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He sits on the edge of a chair and jockeys it, shyly, a l nearer her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they got here afore I did, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they got here. Just after you  left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't a been more wrong, could I?  Bout the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a quieter, remote  voice) Burning villages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's to keep the natives from  runnin' away. No place to come back  to. Been doin' it all over, they  told me up at Limbasi. The Germans  are gonna train 'em into an army and  try to take over the whole of Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor helpless natives!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the same up at the mine when  I got back from Limbasi. A clean  sweep of everything. Just plain luck  I was on the river. They could  certainly use my launch and what's  in 'er, too. Blastin' gelatine, Miss.  Eight boxes of it. An' a lot of canned  grub. An' cylinders of oxygen an'  hydrogen for that weldin' job on the  crusher. Lots o' stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same dead voice) Oh, trust them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as it 'appens, I got the stuff --  an' the launch. Only I've got no  crew, an' she ain't an easy boat to  run single-'anded. Cause them two  boys o' mine just skipped in the  night. Don't know if they were scared  o' me or the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, always) They are fiends out of hell... His  whole life's work smashed. Ruined.  In a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Reverend, eh? (Rose nods) Where's 'e now, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; quietly) He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, that's too bad! Pretty rough  on you, Miss. (embarrassed; trying  to keep the ball  rolling) What'd 'e die of, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really a little  surprised and shocked) Well, now that's just awful! If  they'll up and shoot a Reverend, who  couldn't do 'em a bit a 'arm, there  ain't nobody safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't shoot him, Mr. Allnutt.  But they are accountable to God just  as surely as if they had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ow d'you mean, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They broke his heart. He didn't take  care of himself. He didn't want to  live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is looking into his eyes as if daring him to doubt or disagree. He is timid, perceptive and kind enough not to  argue with her. After a moment, he avoids her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Miss that's cert'nly too bad,  that's all I can say. (both are quiet and  he is uneasy in the  silence. Making  conversation) When'd 'e die, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early this morning. (an odd gesture) He's in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse it, Miss. (delicately) Wot I mean to say is -- the climate  'n all -- quicker you get 'im under  ground the better, if you don't mind  me sayin' so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Got a shovel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. -- Tell ya wot. While I'm  diggin' the grave, you get yer things  together, Miss -- all the things ya  want to take. Then we can clear out  of 'ere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Germans might come back any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should they? They left nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they'll come back, all right.  Lookin' for The African Queen. They'd  dearly love to get their 'ooks on  'er. She's the only power boat on  the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought, Miss, 'ow we might find  somewhere quiet behind an island.  Then we could talk about what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause; then with  quick decision) I'll get my things ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Miss, I'll be quick's I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do the same for me, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he thinks it over, he begins to wonder, literal-minded whether she really would. He goes on out.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: They stand on opposite sides of the new grave. At its hea is an improvised cross, two pieces of wood carefully and  securely wired together. Rose is reading the last lines of the burial service from Methodist or Presbyterian prayerbook. She reads rather badly; (i.E., with the Protestant shadin of "expressiveness") yet between the language and the con between restraint and deep emotion in her voice, it is qu moving. Allnutt, while she reads, is trying to pay polite attention; he even says "Amen", and such, in a sheepish k of way. But his eyes keep sliding uneasily to the jungle; the Germans really do worry him. When she has finished, she stands very silent, for longer than he can take. He tries reasonably hard, but finally h has to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Miss, let's get outa here while  the gettin's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, without looking at him or at the grave, and without speaking, walks away; he picks up his spade and follows. MEDIUM SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT at the edge of the porch. Rose pauses, looks over towards Brother's grave for the l time. Allnutt stands beside her, carrying her suitcase, n wanting to hurry her again, but wishing she'd get a move

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE INSIDE EDGE OF THE PORCH
dialogues.text: By the turn of her head, our eye is led across the scarif clearing. We see the stunted cross and the overwhelming j and, perhaps, a little of the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really meaning it;  but very restrained  and prim) It was very kind of you, Mr. Allnutt,  to think of the cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shucks. Just seemed like he oughta  have one, him a Reverend 'n all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose walks down the steps and towards the river. Allnutt  eagerly keeps pace. We SWING the CAMERA losing the grave, and passing and losing the chapel, and centering them get smaller along the bare ground in the hot sunlight, bringi in the river beyond them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Careful now, Miss. Watch your step.  That's right.

dialogues.speaker: OF AFRICAN QUEEN AT ANCHOR
dialogues.text: PAST BOW) and keeping the noisy SOUND of the water. We pi up Rose and Allnutt as Allnutt helps her aboard. In her l and somewhat narrow skirt she is distinctly old-maidish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the upward  English inflection --  a little as if he  had passed her a  teacup) Thank -- you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt steps aboard. MEDIUM SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT Rose sits down at the rea of the boat and looks around her. Her feet are drawn unde her and knees close together and hands lightly folded on knees (perhaps a lady's scrap of handkerchief in one hand as prim, genteel and ladylike as if, on a holiday afterno she were about to be rowed across an artificial lake fift yards wide. And that is more or less the way she glances  about her in her new surroundings -- politely and  restrainedly, as if a little critical of a parlor somewha humbler than her own. (This SHOT, at the very beginning of her voyage, is to be quite touching, delicate and ironical, and through her ve genteelism and total unconcern for what she is up against an unawareness -- we begin already to sense her complete  intrepidity.) Allnutt pauses to light up a cigarette before getting to  work. He hangs the cigarette inside his upper lip. This  cigarette, dead or alive, is a chronic fixture with Allnu Allnutt kneels in the bottom of the boat and addresses hi to the engine. He hauls out a panful of hot ashes and dum them overside with a sizzle and a splutter. He fills the  furnace with fresh wood from a pile beside him, and soon  smoke appears from the funnel, and we hear the ROAR of th draught. The engine begins to sigh and splutter, and then begins to leak gray pencils of steam. Allnutt peers at hi gauges, thrusts in some more wood, and then leaps forward around the engine, displaying monkeyish agility in handli more tasks than he quite has the hands or the stamina for With grunts and heaves of the small windlass, he hauls in the anchor, the sweat pouring from him in rivers. We see  already that he is physically not a strong man. Allnutt thrusts mightily at the muddy bank with a long po snatches the pole on board again, and then rushes aft to tiller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sweeps her aside unceremoniously (she is astonished bu quickly reassembles herself) and he puts the tiller over  just in time to save the boat from running into the bank. CAMERA IN on Rose, resettling her plumage, and on Allnutt the tiller. The river bank starts to swing in square to t stern. Their eyes are past the CAMERA. MEDIUM SHOT -- (MOVING WITH BOAT) -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT Ros is deeply sad and very tired, but a very quiet kind of  exhilaration is already growing in her; and still more  clearly, her calm and tremendous, unreflecting resolutene begins to show. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yerss...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are the chances of our getting  out through Limbasi on the railway  to the Coast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The railway was in German 'ands when  I was in Limbasi -- and by this time  Limbasi is too, I'll bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do we get out, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got me, Miss. (after a pause) We've got 'eaps of grub 'ere, Miss,  so we're all right, far as that goes.  Two thousand cigarettes, two cases  of gin. We could find a good 'iding  place an' stay there for months if  we want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose's astonishment at this suggestion keeps her from  replying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rattling on) I spose there's goin' to be a fight.  If our troops come from the sea,  they'll attack up the railway to  Limbasi, I spose. In that case, the  best thing we could do would be to  wait round down 'ere an' just go up  to Limbasi when the time came. -- On  the other 'and, they might come down  from British East, an' if they do  that we'd 'ave the Germans between  us and them all the time. Same if  they came from Rhodesia or Portuguese  East. We're in a bit of a fix,  whichever way y'look at it, Miss. (abruptly) Mind takin' the tiller, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt stands up and Rose takes over the tiller, holding the iron rod resolutely. Allnutt goes to his engine and i violently active once more. He pulls open the furnace doo and thrusts in a few sticks of fuel; then he scrambles up into the bow and stands balanced on the cargo. The river studded with islands so that it appears as if there were dozen different channels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Port a little, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE She is confused by the command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Pull it over this side, I mean. --  That's it! Steady!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING SHOT -- THE LAUNCH The boat crawls up a narrow tun of leaf and shade. (If color photography is used, the SHO would be startingly juicy and green -- many shades of gre reflected in rich brown water.) Allnutt comes leaping back over the cargo and shuts off t engine; the propeller stops vibrating. Allnutt dashes into the bow again. Just as the trees (SHO PAST ROSE and her interest in it) begin apparently to mov forward again as the current overcomes the boat's way, he lets go the anchor with a rattling CRASH, and almost with a jerk the launch comes to a standstill. A great silence seems to close in on them -- the silence a tropical river at noon. The only SOUND is the subdued r and gargle of the water. The sober air is filled with a  strange light -- a green light. Allnutt turns from his work at the anchor. He and Rose lo about them and at each other, for a moment mysteriously  bemused by the stillness and by the beauty of the place. sudden quietness and the look of the place are richly  romantic; the two people are quieted by it, but they are  wholly unaware of any such potentiality between them. The are just a couple of oddly assorted derelicts who hardly  even know each other, and don't care for what little they know. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far so good. 'Ere we are safe an'  sound, as you might say. (he beams upon his  surroundings) Not too bad a spot, is it, Miss, to  sit a war out in? All the comforts  of 'ome, includin' runnin' water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs at his joke and is disappointed when Rose does join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid, Mr. Allnutt, that what  you suggest is quite impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ave you got any ideas? (he takes a map out  of his pocket and  hands it to her) 'Ere's a map, Miss. Show me the way  out an' I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose opens the map and starts studying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a while) One thing sure; our men won't come  up from the Congo, not even if they  want to. They'd 'ave to cross the  lake, and nothin' won't cross the  lake while The Louisa is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly) The Louisa? What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an 'undred-ton German steamer,  Miss, and she's the boss o' the lake  'cause she's got a six-pounder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gun, Miss. The biggest gun in  Central Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it wasn't for The Louisa, there  wouldn't be nothin' to it. The Germans  couldn't last a month if our men  could get across the lake... But all  this doesn't get us any nearer 'ome,  does it, Miss? Believe me, if I could  think wot we could do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This river, the Ulanga, runs into  the lake, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Miss, it does; but if you was  thinkin' of goin' to the lake in  this launch -- well, you needn't  think about it any more. We can't  and that's certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rapids, Miss. Cataracts and gorges.  There's an 'undred miles of rapids  down there. Why, the river's even  got a different nyme where it comes  out on the lake to what it's called  up 'ere. It's the Bora down there.  No one knew they was the same river  until that chap Spengler --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got down it. I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss, in a dugout canoe. 'E 'ad  half a dozen Swahili paddlers. Map  makin', 'e was. In fact, that's 'is  map you're lookin' at. There's places  where this ole river goes shootin'  down there like out of a fire 'ose.  We couldn't never get this ole launch  through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While he talks, Rose begins to look restive and vague, as well as discouraged. By the time he is through, she has s up, CAMERA WITH HER; she hardly hears him. She strolls a  little aimlessly PAST THE CAMERA, which SWINGS TO CENTER BACK as she walks forward. As if half in her sleep, she  sidesteps the engine. REVERSE ANGLE -- ROSE (SHOOTING FROM THE BOW) as Rose  sidesteps. She walks toward CAMERA into MEDIUM CLOSE UP,  eyes glazing with dreamlike concentration. She sees somet before and below her eye-level; stops, focusing on it. CLOSE SHOT -- (FROM ROSE'S ANGLE) -- THE GELATINE CASES n marked or labeled as such.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Mr. Allnutt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say is in these boxes  with the red lines on them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT -- ALLNUTT -- (FROM ROSE'S ANGLE) loung and lazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's blastin' gelatine, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (head towards him,  away from CAMERA) Isn't it dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you, no, Miss, that's safety  stuff, that is. It can get wet and  not do any 'arm. If you set fire to  it, it just burns. You can 'it it  wiv an 'ammer and it won't go off --  at least I don't fink it will. It  takes a detonator to set it off.  I'll put it over the side if it  worries you though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply, yet absently  as she turns into  CAMERA) No. We may need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt keeps watching her idly, a little amused and very slightly contemptuous. She wanders away from the boxes, e downcast in thought, and pauses again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Mr. Allnutt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) And what are these queer long round  things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them's the oxygen and hydrogen  cylinders, Miss. Ain't no good to  us, though. Next time I shift cargo,  I'll dump 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply, yet still  more subconsciously  and quietly than  before) I wouldn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She keeps looking down at them, musingly, "subconsciously while CAMERA CREEPS CLOSER to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look like -- like torpedoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Torpedoes" is spoken over: INSERT -- CYLINDERS -- a new and most deadly possible loo SHOT of the cylinders. STILL CLOSER SHOT -- ROSE Slowly she raises her eyes from floor angle to normal; a wild light is dawning in her eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the voice almost  of a medium) Mr. Allnutt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns very slowly towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little bit smug) I'm still right here, Miss, and on a  thirty-foot boat there ain't much of  any place else I could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE -- (FROM ALLNUTT'S ANGLE) walki slowly and somewhat portentously towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (full of the wild  light) You're a machinist, aren't you? Wasn't  that your position at the mine?

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: CAMERA ADVANCING on him at Rose's pace, stopping, looking down, during his last six or eight words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comfortably) Yeah, kind of fixer. Jack of all  trades and master o' none, like they  say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE -- (FROM ALLNUTT'S ANGLE) disconcertin close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you make a torpedo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Come again, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you make a torpedo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't really know what you're  askin', Miss. It's this way, you  see. A torpedo is a very complicated  piece of machinery what with  gyroscopes an' compressed air chambers  an' vertical and horizontal rudders  an' compensating weights. Why, a  torpedo costs at least a thousand  pounds to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He relaxes; his manner is "The State Rests." SWING CAMERA to center Rose, still perched on the gunwale

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a short pause;  unperturbed) But all those things, those gyroscopes  and things, they're only to make it  go, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Go -- and hit what it's goin'  after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the height of her  inventiveness; the  words triumphant and  almost stumbling out) Well! We've got The African Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands up with these words, CAMERA RISING with her,  SHOOTING FROM A LITTLE BELOW; her eager eyes are constant on Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we put this -- this blasting stuff --  in the front of the boat here -- and  a -- what did you say -- deno --  detonator there, why that would be a  torpedo, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- ALLNUTT looking up at her, greatly amused,  almost sardonically admiring her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Those cylinders. They could stick  out over the end, with that gunpowder  stuff in them and the detonator in  the tips where the taps are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then if we ran the boat against the  side of a ship, they'd -- well, they'd  go off, just like a torpedo. (somewhat doubtfully,  in a return to her  submissive feminine  habit) Wouldn't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tremendously amused;  gravely) That might work. (humoring her along,  and a little taken  in by his own fondness  for makeshift) Them cylinders'd do right enough. I  could let the gas out of 'em and  fill 'em up with the gelignite. I  could fix up a detonator all right.  Revolver cartridge'd do. (warming up to it, as  an impossible project) Why, sure, we could cut 'oles in the  bows of the launch, and 'ave the  cylinders stickin' out through them,  so's to get the explosion near the  water. Might turn the trick. But  what would 'appen to us? It would  blow this ole launch and us and  everything all to Kingdom come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't thinking that we should be  in the launch. Couldn't we get  everything ready and have a -- what  do you call it -- a good head of  steam up and point the launch toward  the ship and then dive off before it  hit? Wouldn't that do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might work, Miss. But what are we  talkin' about, anyway. There ain't  nothin' to torpedo. 'Cause The African  Queen's the only boat on the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something to torpedo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' what's that, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Louisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on mention of The  Louisa, a blank,  silent stare of mock  amazement. Then,  patiently) Don't talk silly, Miss. You can't do  that. Honest you can't. I told you  before we can't get down the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spengler did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a canoe, Miss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a German did it, we can, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in no launch. We wouldn't 'ave a  prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know? You've never tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never tried shootin' myself through  the 'ead, neither. (pause) Trouble with you is, you just don't  know nothin' about boats, or water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. They look at each other, Rose much more fixedly searchingly than Allnutt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words, you are refusing to  help your country in her hour of  need, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then --!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs deeply) 'Ave it your own way, Miss -- only  don't blame me, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt stands perplexed and inarticulate, his cigarette  drooping from his upper lip. His wandering gaze strays fr Rose's feet, up her white drill frock to her face; he sta slightly at her implacable expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, let's get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! Now, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Yes, now. Come along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't two hours of daylight  left, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can go a long way in two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt starts to speak; refrains; limps over to windlass and raises the anchor. Rose watches him. CAMERA PANS afte The African Queen as Allnutt backs her out into the chann then turns her nose downstream.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT AND ROSE
dialogues.text: He is at the tiller -- back to CAMERA; Rose, standing loo downstream. The Mission clearing on the bank, which they approach, is unobserved by both of them. Presently pencil of steam begin coming out of the engine. Allnutt, feeling that it requires his attention, signals to Rose, who take his place at the tiller. Allnutt goes to the engine and b to tinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot o' the time I'm going to 'ave  more than enough to do, keepin' the  ole engine goin.' So you might as  well start learnin' to steer right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose nods. Her hand takes a firmer, more authoritative ho on the tiller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) She ain't no one-man boat, the Queen.  Not in the shape she's in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose again shifts her hand a little; and she sits up very straight with her new sense of responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know port from starboard, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's port -- (gesturing) -- an' that's starboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that a bit -- well, silly? Why  not just say left and right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, spose yer facin' the other way  in the boat an' I say "to the left."  You might think I meant to your left,  see, an' move to starboard. It's the  boat ya gotta think of, see? So port's  always that side -- (gesturing) -- an' starboard, that -- an'  forrard's always up there an' aft is  where we are right now -- no matter  what way we're turned around or the  boat is headed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why yes, I see. It's really quite --  sensible, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Okay. Now go easy, Miss --  light on the tiller. Now steer her  just a little to starboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose puts the tiller to starboard; the launch swerves a l to port. She looks at Allnutt, bewildered. Allnutt is qui amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Miss, just straighten her out  again. (using flat hands to  demonstrate) Now looky here. Here's yer tiller. (he extends his right  hand) Here's yer rudder. (he extends his left  hand, below and beyond  his right) They're joined. Tiller sets the  rudder, rudder steers the boat. (he slants both hands  rigidly to one side)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Oh, I see!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose lifts her own hand from the tiller to show; the boat yaws abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiller, Miss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, startled, grabs the tiller and rights her course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blushing) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'S all right, just don't never do  that, 's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, the water -- well -- pushes  against the rudder, where it turns,  and -- sort of drags the boat that  way. Turns it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're catchin' on fine, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks as pleased as if she had personally invented t rudder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now a little to starboard, Miss.  Easy now. (Rose does it right) Fine. Now a little to port. (Rose does it right)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all there is to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ya gotta know how to read the  river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya gotta know the water an' what's  under it, that ya gotta steer clear  of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steer clear of. Why, that's where  that expression comes from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uninterested) Uh huh. Mostly ya can tell it by the  surface o' the water. Now ya see  that long thing out there like a "V"  kinda?

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE LINE
dialogues.text: a long, quiet "V" on the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) That always means a snag. Limb  stickin' up from a dead tree; likes  o' that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay off them "Vs," they're murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks very seriously, almost reprimandingly, towards the "V."

dialogues.speaker: A DIFFERENT PART OF THE RIVER
dialogues.text: The higher light shows it is later in the morning. In the distance, past smooth water, a choppy patch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Now all that little choppin', them's  shallas, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT AND ROSE
dialogues.text: Rose's eyes move from the shallows to steering; she shift course a little, and a long "V" trails past.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD ALONG THE BOAT
dialogues.text: as she resets her course.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: her eyes to starboard. Again the light is later. Rose's f is a shade more pleased and in bloom than before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) What's that queer flat place, Mr.  Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PART OF THE RIVER
dialogues.text: at medium distance off starboard bow, an odd flat turbule in otherwise easy water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) That's a rock. An' it ain't only a  few inches under water. The Queen's  got a shalla draft, an' that's where  we're lucky. 'Cause anythin' ya can't  read on the surface, we're safe to  go right over it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: The BEAT of the engine alters a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only thing to worry us is much of a  breeze. I reckon you know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BEAT of the engine alters still more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes us -- it -- pushes the boat  around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw. It chops the water so --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes forward to the engine.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENGINE
dialogues.text: starts rapping the boiler's safety-valve smartly with a  wrench. After a few socks, it blows off steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud, over his  shoulder, while steam  blows off) Chops it up so bad ya can't see no  signs to warn ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder) Oh. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt is intently busy at the feed pump -- this time, a brief operation. Rose watches him out; he does a little  refueling. (Wood is piled high in the waist now, drying i the sun.) (NOTE: From here on until indicated, no TWO SHOTS. Allnut is amidship, in hot sunlight; Rose, at stern, in cool, br shadow of awning.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the matter, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feed pump choked. An' one o' my boys  dropped sumpin in the safety valve;  can't count on it, ya gotta hit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens when the feed pump  chokes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finishes fueling and sits down and dries his sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whole boiler can blow up. Specially  the shape she's in. This water's  awful muddy. Rots the tubes, plugs  'em up with scale. 'Sides that, the  pressure gauge is kinda on the blink.  Can't count on it fer sure, but ya  can't forget it, neither. Bring 'er  higher'n fifteen pound, the whole  engine starts fallin' apart. An'  much less'n that, she quits. Oh,  come to think of it. Know why I got  to keep the engine goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, so we can go, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't wot I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks blank, and interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause if the engine dies ya ain't  got enough --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. The water doesn't push against  the rudder hard enough to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding approvingly) That's right. No steerage-way. An'  in bad water that's life or death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks at him, for the first time aware that he is as important to navigation as she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you steer wrong we're goners; if  I let the engine die, we're goners,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He adds another couple of pieces of wood. Rose nods, and  takes on both a sense of dignity and a sense of  interdependence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) Oh, she's fulla tricks, this ole  engine. Even the fuelin'. Ya gotta  fuel 'er light an' steady, keep the  pressure right. An' that ain't so  easy as it sounds, Miss. 'Cause wood  makes an awful lotta ash an' chokes  yer draft. Ya gotta plan it all very  careful. Empty the ash pan, ya gotta  figure 'ow it'll change yer draft.  Ya got 'alf a dozen different kinds  o' wood an' every one burns different.  Got to figure on wot the heat o' the  sun does to the boiler, different  times o' day. An' that safety valve.  An' the water pipes keep springin'  leaks, an' the water gauge just works  when she's a mind to. (he looks over the  whole engine with  affection) You got to know 'ow she's feelin',  Miss -- keep a step ahead of 'er.  Right now she's got 'er best foot  forrard 'cause there's a stranger  aboard. But don't be took in, Miss.  Wait till you see 'er in a mean  streak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts on a little more fuel, and lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOILER AND ENGINE HEAD-ON
dialogues.text: like an altar. Allnutt lounges in one side of the SHOT li an acolyte, and quietly watches toward Rose, steering.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: steering. There is something regal about the way she sits holding the tiller, as though it were a scepter.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROW OF THE LAUNCH
dialogues.text: as it noses upstream along a narrow channel. A swerve and steadying; the prow advances into MEDIUM CLOSE UP; the an starts to drop. Before it hits the water:

dialogues.speaker: THE FA
dialogues.text: with SPLASH and RATTLE of anchor and chain o.s., as Allnu rushes into the SHOT and shuts off steam. The pencils of  steam abruptly fade and drift.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: standing very attentively. PAST HIM, a wall of leaves sho that the boat, after a couple of inches of drift, stops  gently. He still stands attentive, as if he were listenin in the abrupt new silence. He is much more grimy and swea than before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
