dialogues.text: It's 'ot work, ain't it, Miss? I  could do with a drink.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He goes to the locker beside Rose, produces two dirty ena cups. Watching him, Rose frowns slightly. Then, from unde the bench he drags out a wooden case. From the case he br out a bottle. He opens the bottle, proceeds to pour a lib portion into one of the cups.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: watching with a kind of fascination.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he makes a movement with the bottle toward the second  cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ave one, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified whisper) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Gin, Miss. And there's only river  water to drink it with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled) No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dips the empty mug overside. He turns back straight an with care, decants the water into the gin.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is in conflict between her intensifying fascination, her sense of actually watching something forbidden and ev outrageous. Impulses play through her, covertly suggested her face, to protest, to appeal to his better nature, eve to snatch the drink from him. And now a new shading enter her face. All she has seen up to now as mere preparation sin: now she is witnessing Sin itself. Something related fear begins to enter her face.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He slaps casually at a mosquito, and lifts the mug for a  second swig.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: eyes still more fixed, fascinated and full of wild doubts and suppositions.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: Allnutt lowers the mug. Happier now than before, he glanc at Rose in an impersonal way; looks away; looks back in d at her, mildly puzzled by what he sees, but not intereste

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: as she watches him very sharp. She is puzzled by how quie and peaceable he is, but she knows better than to trust h She is waiting for the trouble she is sure is bound to co o.s., Allnutt hiccups slightly. She tightens and withdraw little more, then comes to a standstill.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT, (FROM ROSE'S VIEWPOINT)
dialogues.text: He looks up again, a little more puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin' the matter, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shortly) No.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: Still a bit puzzled, he raises his mug and finishes his d off. Across this nice, long drink:

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: Rose's whole body and posture is as withdrawn, pinched an tense as her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (setting down his cup) Now, Miss, 'ow 'bout some tea?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: By the way she lets out a long, long-held breath, we real for the first time the extremity of tension she has been  under. PULL AWAY to INCLUDE ALLNUTT, as Rose relaxes all over, a but trembling, between relief and her ravenous need for t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (able to speak now) Ohhh! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS with Allnutt as he goes over to the boiler. H draws hot water into the two cups, then places them on th bench before her and makes tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stirring) 'Course it tastes a bit rusty, but  you can't 'ave everything. (a little formally) Sugar, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also a little formally) 'k you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little bit caught  by her tea-party  manner; bashfully) don't mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt brings out a lantern and lights it. They both dri She takes a ladylike trial sip; then really guzzles as ne before. Sweat starts out on her forehead and she shuts he eyes. Across her bringing down the cup:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a tea-wet voice,  more relaxed and  female than at any  time before) It's simply delicious!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised, and  somewhat pleased) Not 'alf bad, is it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tastes his again. Living to himself, he has not been m interested in taste and such. Rose sets down her cup and, angling her sharp, long-sleev elbows high, extracts a long pin from her hat, lays it be her and lifts the big, dark hat from her head and lays th beside her too, and carefully thrusts the pin back into t hat and briefly tidies her tight hair. Then, picking up h cup again, she drains the last of her tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out her cup) If you please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. (he starts the business  of making tea again) 'Ow long you been out 'ere, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from the midlands, ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manchester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever get 'omesick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes over and gets crackers and tinned meat out of the locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd give my eye teeth to be back on  a Saturday night, rubbin' elbows  like they say -- all the jostlin'  an' the noise an' the music -- ain't  nothin' can touch it for cheering a  chap up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always Sunday afternoons I think  of -- the peace and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are eating the meat and crackers as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember very much about the  Sundays. I was always sleeping it  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They finish eating. For a few seconds they listen to the  quiet soliloquy of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Didn't see no crocodiles in this  arm, Miss, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crocodiles? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shallas for 'em here. An' current's  too fast. (he coughs, a little  self-consciously) I could do with a bath, 'fore supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spontaneous,  unconsidered) I'd like one too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is a little surprised at herself, but not troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) I'll go up in the bows an' hang onto  the anchor chain. You just stay back  'ere an' do what you like to, Miss.  Then, if we don't look, it won't  matter.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is semi-aware of a change in herself, but still  irresistibly spontaneous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant) Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) Very well, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks towards the bow, sidestepping the engine. Bring SOUND of water a little.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Rose looks after him, checking the six-inch width of the  funnel which will stand between them; not much concerned. While she watches, she is undoing her dress at its cuffs at its high neck. She stands and takes it off over her he with a voluminous motion. She starts to remove an underga and hesitates, frowning a little; compresses her lips and clearly, decides not to remove the garment.

dialogues.speaker: THE FUNNEL
dialogues.text: centered, in the lamplight. The water SOUND rises another fraction; other SOUNDS fade a little.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE'S FEET IN THE WATER --
dialogues.text: not more than shin-deep. (She is sitting on the gunwale.) The water distorts and drives and sways them a little and she is moving them gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her head bent forward, she is watching and quietly enjoyi her feet in the water. There is a little NOISE o.s.; her eyes slip a little in t direction of the bow.

dialogues.speaker: PAST ENGINE AND FUNNEL
dialogues.text: A dim grayish-white shape lowers itself over the bow.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: eyes not too quickly forward. She is not shocked, excited or self-conscious; just calmly interested. (o.s., prodigi KICKINGS and SPLASHINGS and WHOOSHINGS as Allnutt takes h bath.) Slowly her head goes lower in the SHOT and her hea and shoulders begin to twist as she turns to cling to the gunwale. Bring up WATER SOUND a little. As she lets her b loose into the water, CAMERA SWINGS loose along it; it is clear as she lengthens out and submerges that she is wear bloomers and camisole.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE'S FACE
dialogues.text: clinging to the low, stern gunwale, as her arms stretch.  There is a deep and delicate sensuous enjoyment in her fa her body lifts out full length behind her, a dim and wate addled blur. Then she pulls herself up towards the boat a strongly as she can; her wet, strapped shoulders rise, an one elbow clamps over the gunwale.

dialogues.speaker: SUITCASE
dialogues.text: Over SOUNDS of her vigorous drying o.s., the insect- and  moisture-proof tin suitcase or box in which Rose has pack all her worldly goods. It is open. By lantern light some its contents are visible; a few garments and undergarment neatly folded; her prayer- or service-book and her Bible; and a group photograph of Rose and Brother and their fami in which the intention is to anchor Rose deep in English  puritanism. Perhaps eight seconds are allowed for a look this photograph; then Rose's thin, cleansed hands lay in dark dress in which she began this voyage; it is neatly  folded; it covers not only the picture but also the relig books.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Her head emerges from the white drill dress into which sh is shuffling herself; the head, with its slightly dampene hair (which is still pinned up, but strands are loose) lo so refreshed and integrated in the lantern light that it as if it were brand new. With somewhat freer motions than she has made before, she pulls, straightens and pats the  dress, and buttons it at the bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Are you ready, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances past her shoulder towards him as she wrings o a damp undergarment, overside. Allnutt comes past the eng out of the shadows, into SHOT, carrying a couple of rolle rugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better sleep 'ere under the  awnin', Miss, 'case it rains. 'Ere's  a coupla rugs. There ain't no fleas  in 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unrolls a rug and spreads it on the bottom of the boat he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrard, Miss. I can fix up a sorta  bed outa them cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The -- explosives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spreads the other rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Miss. Won't do 'em no 'arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea is queer to Rose, but everything is now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little curtly) All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be sure you cover up good. Gets a  bit chilly on the river, towards  mornin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt returns into the bow. SWING and HOLD CAMERA a cou of seconds on the shadows; he is vaguely visible and ther are the SOUNDS of his arranging the gelatine cases.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: finishing her hair into the second of two short, tight br She reaches into the tin box and under the dark dress and brings out the folded spare clothing. SOUND of the pictur rattling against the bottom. With one hand she puts her h and her comb in on top. She closes the box. HOLD on the c box a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: On one rug and beneath another, in her dress, Rose arrang the spare clothes as a pillow and settles her head; from instant it settles she is immensely but not unhappily tir Over Allnutt's line, o.s., her eyes focus and follow his  sentence, sleepily in the lantern light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) I'll turn out the light if you're  ready, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light on her face begins to dwindle.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: at the lantern. He turns it down. He neither looks at Ros nor takes squeamish care not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, impersonally,  when the light is  very low) 'Night Miss.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: in the lowered light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as quietly and  impersonally) Good night, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o.s., the SOUND of his blowing out the lantern; darkness. The darkness is almost total for a second; then there is  faint visibility. o.s., very subdued, the brief SOUNDS of Allnutt's settling-down; then silence from him. Deeply subdued, the SOUNDS of water slowly dwindle and di entirely, and Rose's eyes are closed. Her mouth softens a little and opens a little; in sleep her face is even more deeply virginal than when she is awake. But now in her sl one hand moves up to her throat and slips inside her dres next the skin.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: in a similar hovering SHOT, asleep in his nest of explosi boxes. He is not snoring, but with each exhalation his li blow out lightly, with a small SOUND of "Puhhh" -- "Puhhh In his sleep, comfortably, his fumbling hand scratches hi haunch. There is no sound of water.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS TOP OF AWNING
dialogues.text: It is raining, quietly but firmly.

dialogues.speaker: VERTICAL
dialogues.text: It is raining into his face. Not quite waking, he pulls h blanket over his face.

dialogues.speaker: VERTICAL
dialogues.text: as the pulled-up blanket exposes them to the quietly  increasing rain. They pull up under the blanket like a to snail into its shell.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT'S FACE
dialogues.text: He is peering disconsolately from under the torn blanket. The rain is increasing. He glances aft.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: The rain is bristling meanly all over the hunched blanket he gets up, wrapping it around him, and walks past CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He comes in under the leaky awning and on into a

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he comes under the awning as quietly as he can, clearl trying not to wake up Rose. He lies down beside her, CAME TILTING and bringing ROSE IN CLOSE UP, and rising into  VERTICAL TWO SHOT above them. Rose is asleep. He is being just as discreet and careful he can, but the margin of dryness is narrow; in avoidance leakiness, and efforts to settle himself comfortably, he  jostles her awake. She wakes up, facing him (his head and body are turned from her) and instantly assumes the worst him. In profound shock and outrage, she sits up and clutc her rug about her -- though she is wearing a dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Allnutt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning, murmuring) Sorry I woke you, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across his line; her  eyes cold blaze) What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He meets her eyes and understands what she thinks of him. is very much astonished and embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blimey, Miss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (measuring her words,  with her really  terrifying quiet  anger) Get out -- this instant!

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He feels an explanation is hopeless and is beyond words  anyhow. He gets up out of the SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: settling down prostrate again. Her eyes follow him in col fury.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he walks humbly out into the rain. A splendid outburst of THUNDER and LIGHTNING blinds and  deafens the SCREEN, and the rain really cuts loose.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: The thunderbolt makes her leap like a salmon; spray from rain gets at her face, even under the awning. Now she  understands and she is a bit embarrassed and sorry; her  changed eyes look at Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He is sitting, hunched, in the open, patiently adjusting blanket over his head. He is facing away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voice is barely audible in smashing rain. He does not hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling loudly) Mr. Allnutt!

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He turns his head sadly towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud, o.s.) You may come in out of the rain, Mr.  Allnutt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks unsure of himself, but gets up and comes towards her. He stumbles against an awning stanchion and gets a  cataract down his neck and comes along under the profusel leaky awning towards Rose, stooping, then lying down and  adjusting his bedding; he is whimpering gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Miss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I give you such a turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's quite all right, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Miss. Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away from her and tries to make himself comforta A quick drop-drip-dropping of water starts directly into face. He miserably pulls his head out of the way and it d loudly onto the boards beside him. Back to her, Allnutt  huddles into the dry space, doing his best not to touch h yet to stay dry. As CAMERA DESCENDS INTO CLOSE UP OF BOTH, he has already  dropped off. Upon one elbow she hovers over him, watching him, with a strange cool virginal tenderness. Splattering of rain which have hit the bench above them, spray his  sleeping face. Gently but inhumanly, as if he were an ugl little doll, she draws a corner of her rug across him, to protect him.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: moving down the river. The water is almost painfully brig in the midday sun.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: at the tiller. There is a new shading of pleasure and  confidence in her expression. She is almost smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: in the killing sunlight, and beside the devastating heat fire and boiler (an extreme shimmering of heat waves); he half-drowned in sweat, yet his face is unconcerned as he  oils the cylinders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a frightfully strong smell,  isn't it! I suppose it's bound to be  at its worst in the middle of the  day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river. I never realized before  how very strongly it smells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt sniffs at it, curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. So it does, now I notice it.  Guess I'm on the water so much, I  forget all about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like marigolds. Stale ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tries again) Don't guess I ever smelt no marigolds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they smell just like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do, huh? Not a very good smell for a  flower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're very pretty, though.  Marigolds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts on some more fuel. o.s., a NOISE of soft ROARING  begins. Allnutt's eyes hear it and look mean and happy; h starts aft.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he sits down, with cruel and secret pleasure, the ROAR loudens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all innocence) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that roaring sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (licking his chops) Oh, that? Rapids, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? So soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just around the bend. (pause) Kind of dangerous. (pause) P'raps I better take over, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be ready to -- but I'd like to  try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gloating) Well -- maybe that's a good idear at  that, Miss. (malicious) Learn by doin', like they say.

dialogues.speaker: THE RAPIDS
dialogues.text: Shooting against the prow of The African Queen, which is  charging downstream quite rapidly. The NOISE of water is  joltingly louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Past him, wild water, rocks, a swiftly moving, ragged sho He is pretending to tinker with the engine, in order to l Rose alone with her fear. He is a little scared, knowing  that Rose is a neophyte at steering and being a woman, ma get rattled -- but mainly he is feeling fine -- by God,  this'll big rapids. He takes time off for a quick glance  back at her (o.s.); turning back to his tinkering, his fa is even more satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Her face is extraordinarily chiseled and tense; her eyes hard as diamonds. We can easily suppose her expression to one of cold terror, as Allnutt does.

dialogues.speaker: NOTE
dialogues.text: This SCENE is to last about thirty seconds. The rapids ar to be rough enough to excite and to give a considerable s of hazard, but they are mild compared to what will be see later on. A fair amount of the SCENE is just racing throu loud, ragged water, but there are to be perhaps three rea hazards. They might, for instance, be: the two rocks the  scene opens with; a buried rock, just spotted and avoided the nick of time, scaring the daylights out of Allnutt an tightening Rose's face still more into this simulacrum of fear (he is comforted out of his own fears, seeing this f and, caught between rocks, jutting into their only availa channel, a large jagged tree-limb, bony-looking as antler There's no way out: Rose drives dead against it with an  instinct for the angle which will bring against it the mo powerful leverage: it hits hard and there is a tremendous NOISE of CRACKING and BREAKAGE. Within another couple of  seconds they are in quieter water; within a couple more, water is almost normal, the ROAR is fading. The boat has  slowed down. The ENGINE SOUND is near normal balance; Ros distinctly relaxes, and sits down; Allnutt relaxes at his tinkering, and finishes it off with a bit of a flourish.  (From the breaking of the branches, SHOOT FROM AMIDSHIPS, sternward, on Rose past Allnutt.) While he stands, back to Rose, finishing his tinkering,  Allnutt looks happy as a clam and thoroughly smug.  Everything's the way he wants it, now. He checks his gaug o.s., and turns away, and strolls back towards Rose with  something of a swagger.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as Allnutt seats himself a little too smugly on the stern at right angle to Rose. He sizes her up for a couple of  seconds, greatly relishing the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly gloating) Well, Miss, had enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough? Of what, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White water. Rapids. Now ya got a  taste of it, how d'ya like it? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very much indeed. (Allnutt's eyes change;  his mouth falls open  a little) I'd never dreamed that any -- any  mere -- er -- physical experience  could be so -- so stimulating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just keeps looking at her. He begins to need a cigaret Without taking his eyes off her he gets one out. Rose is  quite unaware of what she is doing to Allnutt -- much  friendlier in her tone than ever before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fishing up the mot  juste) So -- exhilarating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt puts the cigarette between his lips, and gets out match; he is still watching her; every moment, he is more and more deeply aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I notice that near rocks, the water  seems to push away from the rock.  One must take that into account in  steering, mustn't one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt scratches a match; it fails to light. He gets ano

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've only known such --  excitement a few times before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His look inquires of her. He gets a match lighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few times, in my dear Brother's  sermons, when the Spirit was really  upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt raises the match to light his cigarette. His eyes leave hers for the lighting. His eyes look bruised and si his hands are shaking. He stands up, in quiet desperation to beat it into her thick head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at her hopelessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just managing to  shape the sound) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I steered rather well for a beginner,  didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without spirit) Not so bad, Miss, considerin'. But  that wasn't such bad water -- nothin'  compared to what's farther on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hardly wait! (Allnutt looks as if  he could wait quite  a while. A pause) Now that I've had a taste of it I  don't wonder you love boating!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her one last flabbergasted, hopeless look, wheel abruptly and walks away -- CAMERA SWINGING, losing Rose - and sits near the engine, turned away from her, looking  crumpled and beaten. He is still shaking his head. o.s.,  blithely, Rose hums the opening bars of Guide Me, O Thou  Great Jehovah. Allnutt shifts a little as if to look at her; hasn't the  heart to; shudders faintly; and stretches his shaking han toward the furnace.

dialogues.speaker: GIN BOTTLE, (TWO-THIRDS FULL)
dialogues.text: as Allnutt pulls out cork, with luscious SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: SHOT slightly favors Allnutt. Late twilight; the boat is  moored near a bank. Rose is taking a swallow of steaming  tea; she lowers her cup. Allnutt's full mug of tea stands beside him on the bench, untouched. Rose watches him with interest. Allnutt lifts the bottle drink; he raises his eyes and meets hers; sullen and defi He puts the bottle in his mouth, cocks it up and drinks d of neat gin; past the bottle, the hostility of his eyes  increases. Rose looks perplexed. The rum gin burns him; he has a brief spasm of the gaspin shakes. He tries not to show this, and avoids her eyes. Genuine concern blends with her perplexity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Is something the matter, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He meets her eyes again, sullen, a little bitter. His eye still on hers, he raises the bottle, cocks it up showily, and drinks again -- looking at her past the bottle. The g makes sweat start out on his forehead. He keeps on, thoug taking a deep drink, watching her all the time. Finally h brings the bottle down. His eyes go out of focus, against his will. And against his will and pride, he wipes the sw off his forehead with the palm of his hand, and the sweat from his hand onto his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently, again) Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her with angry reproach. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (already affected by  the gin; proud and  sullen) Nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. He raises the bottle; lowers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' you'd understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after waiting him  out) I want to understand. I just can't  imagine what's the matter. It's been  such a pleasant day. (pause) What is it, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt looks at her bitterly. Suddenly he looks mad and  stands up. Just as suddenly he sits down again. This make him sore at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly; after a  pause) All this fool talk about The Louisa.  Goin' down the river...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean we ain't goin' to do nothin'  of the sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs a drink on this, but Rose interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, of course we're going! What an  absurd idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling his oats and  his gin; mimicking  nastily) What an absurd idea! What an absurd  idea! Lady, I may be a born fool,  but you got ten absurd idears to my  one, an' don't you forget it! (pause. Speechless  with scorn and  resentment) Huh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a glimmer of  tact) Why don't you want to go, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I want to blow up sumpin'  for? You tell me. Yeah. You tell me.  That's all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Why don't you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sullenly) Already come further'n I ever meant  to. Don't hardly even know the river,  this far down. (bitterly and a little  incoherently) Only come this far 'cause there you  was all by your lonesome, lost your  brother and all -- wot you get for  feelin' sorry for people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Why, Mr. Allnutt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This river. That's why. An' Shona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shona!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking her tone,  nastily) Shona! (pause) If there's any place along the whole  river the Germans'll keep a lookout,  it'll be Shona. 'Cause that's where  the old road ferries over from the  South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they can't do anything to us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they can't, eh? They got rifles,  maybe machine guns, maybe even  cannons, an' just one bullet in that  blastin' gelatine an', Miss, what's  left of us would be in bits and  pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll go by at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, we won't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with asperity) Now why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause the rapids start just a little  ways below Shona, an' they ain't  nobody in his right mind 'ud tackle  'em even in daylight, let alone at  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll go in daylight. We'll go  on the far side of the river from  Shona, just as fast as ever we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sudden realization.  Boozily, sorely) -- Say, who do you think you are,  all this we'll do this an' we'll do  that? 'Oose boat is this, any'ow?  'Oo asked you aboard? Huh? Huh? You  crazy, psalm-singin', skinny old  maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the first phase of realization, her lower lip thrusts like a shovel or like the lower lip of a baby within a st throw of crying, and her eyes look soft with dampness. Th she catches her lower lip between her teeth in her effort restrain herself, and her eyes harden with self-disciplin Then she doesn't need the teeth any more. Her lips are ti and thin. Her whole face is edgy. Her eyes are hard with  bitter resentment and with hatred. Slowly, without moving her head or altering her face, she lifts her tea into the SHOT and drinks, and lowers the cup out of the SHOT. Her  face grows still harder and more immovable. Against this, o.s., mostly in breathy, lonesome undertone on one or two phrases loudly and assertively, Allnutt is  singing, rottenly and inchoately, some part of the follow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; singing) Gimmy regards ter Leicester Square  Sweet Piccadilly an' Myefair, Remember  me to the folks darn there They'll  under-sta-and.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW FADE on Rose as first daylight begins to appear. FAD

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He is prostrate beside the engine in early morning sunlig Except that his eyes are closed, he looks as if he had be dead for about a day. o.s., the HARSH SCRAPING of broken glass against wood and the happy shouts of early birds; also the quiet gurgling river water. For a few seconds, these sounds don't even register. Then they reach into him and he winces profoundly. (NOTE: Sudd and painfully exaggerate all SOUNDS.) His dry mouth works little. His eyelids twitch. The eyes open -- and shut fas light is painful to him. o.s., the SOUND of a small avalanche of broken glass bein thrown overside and hitting the water. Rose's hand reaches down past the far side of his head an picks up an empty bottle and an almost empty bottle, and  withdraws from SHOT. Allnutt registers vague awareness th someone is near, but doesn't open his eyes. o.s., again painfully exaggerated, the SOUND of the gin c being DRAGGED along the deck. His eyes still shut, Allnut suffers intense pain. He opens his eyes, squeezes them ti shut (which hurts him badly), opens them again, and gazes past CAMERA in listless, uncomprehending horror.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is in painfully bright, early sunlight, and she is we white. She has lifted the bottles and the case to the ben beside her. She kneels on the bench, aloof to the CAMERA. She tosses the empty bottle astern. She is on the verge o disposing of the gin in the nearly-empty bottle; on secon thought she sniffs at it with mistrustful curiosity; her  reaction indicates disgust with the smell, with Drink, an with Allnutt. She turns the bottle upsidedown and lets th contents pour overside into the river, and tosses the bot contemptuously astern.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: His eyes are bloodshot and are swimming with tears induce by the light. He doesn't quite take in what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whimpering moan,  pure misery; not for  what he sees) Oh... Oh...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt shuts his eyes. o.s., the GLUG-GLUG-GLUGGING of a full bottle. He looks again. He begins to comprehend and  what he sees is, to him, terrible and almost unbelievable

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with deeper feeling  but quietly; reacting  now to what he sees) Oh...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o.s., the SOUND of another flung bottle hitting the water and of another being opened. Allnutt, using all his stren manages to lift his head from the floor. The effort is so exhausting and the pain so excruciating that he just lets fall; the bang is even more agonizing. He licks his dry l with his dry tongue and tries speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a voice like a  crow) Miss.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is emptying gin and pays him no attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pays him no attention except to turn the inverted bot to absolute verticle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have pity, Miss! (pause; SOUND of "glug- glug" o.s.) Miss? ("glug-glug") Oh, Miss, you don't know what you're  doin'... I'll perish without a hair  o' the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND, o.s., of bottle hitting water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Ain't your property, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND, o.s., of a new bottle being opened. CAMERA CREEPS  CLOSER on Allnutt, whose eyes become those of a man in he who knows, now, that his sentence is official, and perman With terrible effort, he lifts his head and shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: EXPOSURE
dialogues.text: She is emptying gin. She hears the SOUNDS of Allnutt's mo o.s. Her hard face hardens still more. She glances toward him, continuing to pour.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He is with great pain and effort getting himself to his k and his arms onto the side bench. It may seem for a momen that he is going to try to come at Rose and make a strugg for it, but no: he now gets his knees to the bench and ha his body far out over the gunwale and drinks ravenously o the muddy water. He overhangs so far that he is in clear  danger of falling in.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is watching him. SOUNDS, o.s., of the gin emptying, a of his drinking. She is aware he may fall in and she does care.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He finishes drinking and tremulously pulls himself back, turns, and collapses into a sitting position on the bench

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is opening another bottle and casually watching him, as casually looking away. She is pitiless, vengeful,  contemptuous, and disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: His head hangs between his knees; his hands hang ape-like beside his ankles. After a little he is able to lift his  head. He props his temples between his hands and his elbo on his knees. He is so weak that one elbow slips, letting his head fall with a nasty jolt and a whimper of anguish. sets himself more carefully solid and gazes ahead of him the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She ignores him completely; she lays the flap back from s canned meat.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He gets out and fumblingly lights a cigarette; his hands shaky. He takes a deep drag and it gives him a dreadful f of coughing. He glances toward her piteously.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is slicing bread; she ignores him. His coughing is lo o.s.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: Recovered from his spasms, he timidly tries a lighter dra This time he can taste it. It tastes foul. He puts it out carefully, for later use, takes one look at it, and  disconsolately tosses it overside. He looks again towards Rose. He looks away again. He sighs deeply and buries his face in his hands. o.s., their SOUND abnormally sharp, the birds are singing like mad.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is sitting on a side-bench in the shade of the awning calmly reading her Bible. She is in a clean white dress,  exactly like the one she wore yesterday. Not a hair is ou of place in her tight hair-do. Her bare feet are crossed  demurely at the ankles. She sits up straight. She looks v cool, considering the weather. PULL BACK, bringing in her day's work: up past her left,  pinned to the edge of the awning, hang her newly-laundere dress and undergarments, full of sunlight. There are a fe ineradicable streaks of grease in the dress. On the bench her right, her sewing-basket and some evidently finished  sewing chores. o.s., the steady GURGLING of river water among the treero of the bank; the nervous SCRAPING of a razor.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENGINE
dialogues.text: It looks much cleaner than ever before. (Same SOUNDS o.s. The CAMERA IS RISING as the SHOT OPENS. It soon brings in Allnutt's head, past the engine, very hot-looking in stro sunlight. He is shaving. SLOW PANNING DETAIL. A welter of wet footprints and splas soapy deck, Allnutt's clean bare heels glistening high in the SHOT as he stands shaving. CAMERA TILTS and brings in drowned sliver of soap. Allnutt's filthy clothes, a wet a arrestingly filthy towel. Same SOUNDS o.s., razor-scraping a little UP. Past the back of Allnutt's head on his close reflection i small mirror, hung from a funnel-stay; past that, Rose. Allnutt is shaving; Rose, in b.g., is reading. It is pain to take off as much beard as Allnutt has been carrying, a he is not a man who takes pain easily; but he does his be to keep his reactions private, and by now he is nearly  through. He is whistling softly against his teeth, and  frowning at his reflected work with the concentration of surgeon. He knows, however, that he is visible to Rose, a unwisely keeps glancing towards her (she never looks up o thanks to this, he lets the razor slip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow... cut myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances sharply at Rose to see if she has taken any no She does not glance up. Allnutt resents this bitterly. He finishes shaving, and strokes his smooth cheeks with  satisfaction. Rose turns a page. With a Rembrandt's patie and concern, he perfects, with his comb, the ideal coiffu with an artistic quiff along the forehead. His eyes go va He treats himself, in reflection, to his idea of what the Lord of Creation should look like. Then he glances toward Rose, who keeps on reading. His look is aloof, miles abov her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND o.s., of Allnutt's entrance past the engine. She do not glance up, but her eyelids flicker.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He walks a couple of steps towards her in the brilliant  sunlight, swaggering a little. Then he stands still, the  Stag at Eve, looking at her with a certain high contempt. is obviously challenging response and recognition. He get none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause;  scornfully) Huh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks in under the shade of the awning and into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he sits down. After another silence, he decides on a n approach. He arranges his face to express high good humor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly) Well, Miss, 'ere we are, everything  ship-shape, like they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL AWAY to TWO SHOT of Rose and Allnutt, as he awaits h reaction. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Great thing to 'ave a lyedy aboard,  with clean 'abits. Sets me a good  example. A man alone, 'e gets to  livin' like a bloomin' 'og. (no answer) Then, too, with me, it's always --  put things orf. Never do todye wot  ya can put orf till tomorrer. (he chuckles and looks  at her, expecting  her to smile. Not a  glimmer from Rose) But you: business afore pleasure,  every time. Do yer pers'nal laundry,  make yerself spic an' span, get all  the mendin' out o' the way, an' then,  an' hone-ly then, set down to a nice  quiet hour with the Good-Book. (he watches for  something; she  registers nothing) I tell you, it's a model for me,  like. An inspiration. I ain't got  that ole engine so clean in years;  inside an' out, Miss. Just look at  'er, Miss! She practically sparkles. (Rose evidently does  not hear him) Myself, too. Guess you ain't never  'ad a look at me without whiskers  an' all cleaned up, 'ave you, Miss? (no look) Freshens you up, too; if I only 'ad  clean clothes, like you. (huh-uh) Now you: why you could be at 'igh  tea. (no recognition from  Rose) 'Ow 'bout some tea, Miss, come to  think of it? Don't you stir; I'll  get it ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose does not stir. Allnutt is running low. A little sile now. He watches her read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) 'Ow's the book, Miss? (no answer) Not that I ain't read it, some --  that is to say, me ole lyedy read me  stories out of it. (no answer; pause) 'Ow 'bout readin' it out loud, eh,  Miss? (silence) I'd like to 'ave a little spiritual  comfort m'self. (silence; he flares  up) An' you call yerself a Christian! (silence) You 'ear me, Miss. (silence) Don't yer? (silence; a bright  cruel idea. Louder,  leaning to her) Don't yer? (silence. Suddenly,  at the top of his  lungs) HUH??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In spite of herself she flinches; but swiftly controls it

dialogues.speaker: FROM OTHER SIDE OF THE RIVER
dialogues.text: A half mile of hot, empty water, then jungle, silent on a dream of heat. On the far side the tiny boat and the two  infinitesimal passengers. After two seconds, Allnutt's "HUH?" is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her face are victory, cruelty, and tremendous secret  gratification: a Jocasta digesting her young. The ECHO comes. Over it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second, further echo comes, and dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Heyy!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watchful, listening, he walks out of SHOT; CAMERA LOWERS Rose, whose quiet, pitiless eyes -- wholly unamused -- fo him secretly. The ECHO returns to her; she resumes readin

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING ALLNUTT, (PAST ROSE)
dialogues.text: He wanders all over the boat, CAMERA ALWAYS CENTERING him always shifting past the statue-like reader. He barks lik dog; he yowls like a tomcat; he roars like a lion; he ble like a goat; he crows like a rooster. Finally he sickens it and walks back past her to his old seat at right angle to her.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he sits. Clearly now he is going to try silent decorum in imitation of her. He crosses his ankles in imitation, settles his hands in his lap, and even holds his head pri watching her. But something itches him under the arm and scratches -- first covertly and insufficiently, then to h heart's content. His exertions have worked up quite a swe the midges of late afternoon convene enthusiastically abo his head. He looks bitterly towards Rose.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: There isn't a bug near her. Taking her time, she finishes the last page and, not hurrying, but without pause, start right in on Genesis. SWING CAMERA, losing Rose, bringing Allnutt into CLOSEUP. hates her and the Good Book. PULL AWAY into TWO SHOT -- of Rose and Allnutt. After a f moments of silent, motionless tableau, Allnutt hating, Ro reading, he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feller takes a drop too much once in  a while. T's only yoomin nyture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remotely) Nature, Mr. Allnutt, is what we are  put into this world to rise above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss, I'm sorry. I 'pologize. There.  What more can a man do than say he's  sorry. Eh? (no answer) You done paid me back, Miss. Didn't  even leave me a drop. (no answer) Come on, Miss. 'Ave a 'eart, can't  ya? Fair's fair. (no answer) Miss, I don't care wot ya say, long  's you say somepin. (no answer) I'll be honest with ya, Miss: I just  can't stand no more of it. I ain't  used to it, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think it was your nasty  drunkenness I mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A foolish, helpless gesture from Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) Well -- wot else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lied to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with earnest dignity) Lied? Oh no, Miss. Lyin's one thing  I don't never do. Not unless there's  no way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised we'd go down the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is so honestly flabbergasted, this brings him up on hi feet, goggling at her. When he can find words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Miss! Is that wot it's all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws a deep breath and sits down closer to her than  before. He begins quietly, with great patience and  reasonableness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now for the last time, Miss. Just  try and listen, won't you? Try to  understand. (Rose looks at him  coldly; her jaw is  set) It's sure death a dozen times over  down this river. I 'ate to disappoint  you, Miss. But don't blyme me. Blyme  the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Well, I'm takin' my promise back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and strides away, CAMERA CENTERING HIM, and wa past the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches after him. She is not a hundred per cent sure victory; only ninety-five or so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is asleep on his box of high explosives. o.s., SOUNDS early birds -- and of Rose's bustling, and of a strong br and of leaves. Presently he stirs, groans and opens his e After a moment he glances in her direction.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is readying the fire for tea.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: After a little, Allnutt gives up. He creakily, painfully  rises from his bed and gets up into:

dialogues.speaker: AMIDSHIPS
dialogues.text: He walks towards CAMERA into CLOSE UP and passes engine,  CAMERA SWINGING INTO TWO SHOT of Rose and Allnutt. Rose is thrusting a saucepan of water into the crackling  furnace. Allnutt pauses shyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pitiful effort to  sound casual, and  dignified) G'mornin', Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose straightens up and doesn't even see him, and turns a walks away, CAMERA on her, losing Allnutt. She sits on the stern bench and gets out bread and one mu and a can, and starts opening the can. He does not exist. After a few seconds, he walks into the SHOT, BACK-TO, and sits down on a right-angle bench, a few feet away from he She continues opening the can. He lights a cigarette from the open tin; it is damp and swollen from the night air,  lights slowly, and tastes poorly, but he tries to make th best of it. o.s., the SOUND of hot water joins that of the crackling  fire. Rose gets up with a cloth for the hot handle and wa up past Allnutt into CLOSE UP and OUT OF SHOT. SOUNDS, o.s., of her getting out the water and shutting t door. Allnutt's eyes follow her, wretchedly, wherever she goes. She reenters the SHOT, BACK-TO, and returns to her place, still ignoring Allnutt, and starts fixing tea for herself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is watching her; the last of his staying-power is  dissolving.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is stirring her tea and now she drinks some.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He is watching her and thorough despair is in his eyes, a unconsciously his head begins to shake a little.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Now she is eating bread and canned meat.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He stops shaking his head and just looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) All right, Miss. You win.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She meets his eyes, immediately, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accepting utter defeat) Down the river we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Have some breakfast, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is so moved by this line that he is on the verge of te

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, no. Get up steam. Breakfast can  wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reacts with the quiet hopelessness of a slave; one bea look at her, gets to his feet and walks towards CAMERA an engine, filling SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: THE MORNING
dialogues.text: The boat is going along at full speed. Boat fills most of r.s., a downstream vista of the river, and the bank, l.s. The breeze is strong now; two-foot waves; clear sunlight. calmly exhilarating NOISE of water and, o.s., strong, the SOUND of the engine.

dialogues.speaker: STRAIGHT ACROSS THE BOAT
dialogues.text: He is sitting on the starboard bench, back to the sun,  transferring canned meat to bread. The floor of the SHOT is a high stack of firewood. The le wall of the SHOT is the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., calling  something not fully  distinguishable, as) Which bank is Shona on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting; leaning  his ear towards her) 'Ow's that?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is at the tiller but in spite of cross-bucking the wa she now has the casualness of experience. Except for much more difficult steering, she doesn't have to think much a it now. Her hair is done up, but has blown part free. Her dress is flecked with the dampness of blowing water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Which bank is Shona on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly, o.s.) Left. On a hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Good. The sun will be in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder, gesturing) The sun. Will be in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: It is becoming more real to him now. He glances towards h He sets his breakfast aside, gets up, and goes past the e into the bow section.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Her eyes strain curiously after him.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He walks in among the boxes of blasting gelatine, his fac troubled, and looks down at them.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOXES
dialogues.text: They are disposed irregularly in the sunlight; their red  lines look sinister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as, with face still more troubled, he bends over and lift box.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: The prow and river beyond him; he is stacking the boxes a the port bow. He has stuck a rug between them and the hul Now he stacks the last box and covers it with a rug. He s and looks at the rug a moment, rather helplessly, then tu to CAMERA and into MEDIUM SHOT; his face is still more ba worried. He glances back towards Rose. He stoops and drag the heavy cylinders into the starboard bow, trimming ship He walks back towards the engine, mopping his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is watching him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he comes past the engine, he meets her eye, and looks  away. He goes towards his bench and breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he sits down. He glances towards his gauges and resume eating. But his appetite is not so good now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., not quite  distinguishably) Don't worry, Mr. Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a bullet hits them boxes, there'll  be no time to worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking his knife to use it eating, he suddenly goes still and wary with a new idea. He glances secretly at the knif and secretly towards the engine.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: His face gets still darker with guile. With a clumsy imit of concern for the engine, he gets up and walks out of th SHOT, the open knife in his hand filling the SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: PAST ENGINE
dialogues.text: ROSE STANDING IN BACKGROUND. As he pretends to tinker wit the engine below SHOT, his eyes flicker towards the hose the knife and think, obviously, of danger and of Rose, of whom he is painfully aware. It is clear by his eyes and face that he is trying desper to make up his mind to cut the hose; and delays because h so dreads the consequences with Rose, who is watching him with mild curiosity. The decision is taken out of his han Past him, Rose looks with interest ahead, off the port bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting and pointing) Mr. Allnutt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shifts course sharp to starboard. Allnutt hears her a looks around and sees her pointing, and quickly turns and looks ahead and to port. Great fear comes into his face, also some excitement unrelated to fear.

dialogues.speaker: PAST ALLNUTT AND THE ENGINE
dialogues.text: As a curve opens, the walled hill-town of Shona is disclo Above one building of corrugated iron, a German flag flie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides the fear and excitement in his face, indecisivene reaches the point of agony. Past him, the right bank of t river approaches, moving more and more swiftly.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She is near the bank. She straightens her course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances desperately toward the rubber hosing. INSERT: RUBBER HOSING.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He glances desperately towards Shona. Shona is swinging w into view. People are seen, including two men apparently uniform. Allnutt glances desperately towards his knife. INSERT: He closes the knife and slips it into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: His face is committed helplessly to catastrophe. He turns his head to call to Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder,  as he crouches) Keep as low as ya can, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She nods, and crouches below the benches, her hand still  high to steer. INSERT: THE RUBBER HOSE. as it bursts; a strong spume of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eyes to SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eyes to SOUND. INSERT: The WATER GAUGE slowly drops.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as with frantic speed he gets tape and a piece of flat ru out of his toolbox. INSERT: RUBBER HOSE, as Allnutt claps the rubber to the b hose and starts taping; water still escapes abundantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His desperate face as he works. INSERT: The PRESSURE GAUGE, sinking. INSERT: The WATER GAUGE, still lower. o.s., the engine SOUND slows and fades to a lugubrious  CLANKING, then stops altogether. From here on, very quiet but in all shots on the boat,  steadily LOUDER, a faint RUMBLING ROAR, o.s., the rapids.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: anxious and much interested, but no fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Just turn 'er loose, Miss. Let 'er  drift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks uncomprehending.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He is hard at work. There are no pencils of steam any mor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over shoulder; bawling  desperately in the  silence) Let 'er drift! All we can do!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She nods. She releases the tiller. o.s., the SOUND of a  bullet; followed, seconds later, by the REPORT of a rifle Rose looks towards Shona and towards Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He is working. Water is still splattering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over shoulder) 'Cross our bows, I reckon. Didn't  'it us any'ow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ducks still lower to his work.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: and its occupants, through field glasses, from high bank. Even so, they are small, on the far side of the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. in German) But why didn't they put in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. in German) Probably they're making for the lower  landing.

dialogues.speaker: LOWER LANDING
dialogues.text: Deep in l.s., the lower landing, which is small. High in r.s., The African Queen.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST AND 2ND OFFICERS AND SWAHILI TROOPS
dialogues.text: on hard, bare ground, corrugated iron building, and Germa flag, and a portion of the town, in b.g. 1st Officer is a moderately stupid German. 2nd Officer is moderately intelligent German. The Swahilis, in their whi with their elderly Martini rifles, are all eyes and teeth and excitement -- and eagerness to use their weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) Fire twice more across their bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Officer raises rifle, with telescopic sight.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: raked from stern to stem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. in German) She is adrift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. in German) Fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot moves ahead of the boat. A little kick in the SH as the rifle fires; SOUND o. s. The boat advances into th SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. in German) Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot again leads the boat safely. Some kick, SOUND o. s., and advance of boat as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) She's not turning.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: is opposite the lower landing, still at far shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. in German) She can't. She is adrift.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICERS AND MEN
dialogues.text: 1st OFFICER She could anchor. 2nd Officer has no answer for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Swahili  corporal, in Swahili) Order your men to fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corporal clicks heels and salutes with enthusiasm, an about face, to his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily and bossily,  in Swahili or in  Swahili-esque German) Fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are all eagerness and delight. They hurry forwar into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some fall prone to fire as they have been trained; others stand; several squat where they take aim. It is clear by  their handling of their weapons that they are all farcica lousy shots.

dialogues.speaker: A SHOT ALONG THEIR RAGGED LINE --
dialogues.text: some prone, some standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sweeping  gesture) Fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fire a ragged volley, rifles at all sorts of angles.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: Allnutt is still hard at work. The boat is moving faster, near the bank. There is a peculiar multiple NOISE in the  air, like bees in a violent hurry, accompanied by the SOU of tearing paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crouching still lower  at his work) They got us!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: curious about the sound. Now comes the straggling REPORTS RIFLES; a volley echoing back from cliff to cliff. INSERT: Allnutt completes his taping.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: stepping away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- if we can get up steam in  time, an' the boiler'll stand that  much cold water, an' the mend holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts on a lot of wood, and he gets the pump going,  cautiously. There is a dangerous straining and CRACKLING  SOUND from the boiler as the cold water rushes in. Across it, there is another BUZZING of bullets. Some speckle the water; some hit the heightening rock cliff above and past the boat; the reports arrive and ECHO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; he has  been cringing and  mute during the  buzzing; he speaks  across the reports) If only we don't drift into the back  eddy.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She nods. She is watching anxiously, helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: ALONG STARBOARD
dialogues.text: The fast current in which they drift, and the slow back-e and their dividing line, are visible. SWING SHOT to CENTE along axis of boat and on Allnutt. o.s., there is the SOU of a much faster bullet, and suddenly, causing Allnutt to leap like a stricken faun, the whole boat RINGS like a ha

dialogues.speaker: THE WIRE FUNNEL-STAY
dialogues.text: on portside has parted, close above the gunwale. It hangs loose by the funnel.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: noting and reacting. He turns to Rose, CAMERA SWINGING in TWO SHOT. She has noticed it too, but is not particularly frightened. o.s., there is a METALLIC SMACK. They glance sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: high in the funnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the far side of the funnel. INSERT: WATER GAUGE, rising.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: checking gauges, working hard. INSERT: PRESSURE GAUGE, rising.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: crouching. He adjusts pump to let more water in. The stra SOUNDS intensify. He opens the furnace door.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT, (THROUGH TELESCOPIC SIGHT)
dialogues.text: o.s., the rifle FIRES; the shot kicks.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: as a bullet WHINES past overhead. o.s., the furnace door  CLANKS SHUT and there is an increased SOUND of fire. She  looks reprimandingly towards the bank. We can scarcely se the figures of the officers and men. The rifle REPORT com through.

dialogues.speaker: THE OFFICERS AND MEN
dialogues.text: The men are sheepish and downcast in b.g. The 1st Officer who fired, lowers his rifle. The 2nd Officer has field  glasses. They look at each other. The 1st Officer shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the rifle and takes careful aim.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: He is leading Allnutt just a trifle, and leisurely trying perfect his aim. While he takes his time, the boat crosse the path of the full glare of the sun. He mutters some Ge expletive under his breath, and FIRES into blind glare.

dialogues.speaker: GELATINE BOXES
dialogues.text: A corner of one of the gelatine boxes flies apart in  splinters.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO OFFICERS
dialogues.text: as the 1st Officer lowers the rifle, his eye hurt by glar he hands it back to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) Fire at random.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody happily starts shooting at random. The natives  love it.

dialogues.speaker: ALONG THE FULL LENGTH OF THE BOAT
dialogues.text: PAST ROSE Ahead, the escarpment looms, the right bank nar a deep shadow between them. The ROAR is by now almost  deafening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting as loud as  he can) Man the tiller now -- we'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't understand; she does nothing. He gestures -- manipulation of a tiller. Rose takes it. The SINGING of the bullets is all but inaudible, but thre hit the boat. Allnutt starts the engine. It stammers and  gulps and dies. The boat swings with great speed into dee cool shadow as he tries again. It stammers and catches, a dies.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT PAST ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: The water is terribly swift, but not yet stony; but withi hundred yards ahead there is a terrific cataract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is terrific tension in his face, but he is much too busy to be frightened. Rose's face is a sharpening image her face among the easier rapids. Now that they have come within close, high stone banks, the ROAR is prodigious. Allnutt, below SCENE, is working on the engine.

dialogues.speaker: THE CATARACT
dialogues.text: twice as near.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: The engine catches and rises, just AUDIBLE ABOVE the ROAR WATER.

dialogues.speaker: CATARACT
dialogues.text: They swallow ten of the last twenty yards before the cata

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: standing, looking intensely ahead, hand firm on tiller.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: as it enters upon the cataract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he drops onto his bench next the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Father Who art in Heaven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The African Queen bucks like a bronco. The air is full of spray and of the ROAR of rushing water. Allnutt serves th engine with panic in his soul. Out of the tail of his eye he glimpses rocks flashing past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rides the mad tide like a Valkyrie, weaving a safe co through the clustering dangers. There comes a place where the river widens and the sweep the current takes The African Queen over to the opposite  bank, as if she were no more than a chip of wood. Rose tu at the tiller with all her strength. The bows come around It looks for a space as if the stern would be flung again the rocks. The boat just manages to hold her way. Then a backwash catches her, flinging her out again into  midstream, so that Rose has to force the tiller across wi lightning swiftness. Hardly are they straight again when banks close in upon them and Rose must instantly pick out fresh course, through the rocks that stud the surface in  flurries of white foam.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: plunging down a narrow ribbon of water between vertical f of rock.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he waves at the engine and shouts something that is dr out by the ROAR of the waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head and her lips form the words: "I can't hear."

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: gesticulating frantically. He moves forward into a CLOSE and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Need fuel! We got to get fuel!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She nods, to show her understanding of their plight.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: There is a natural dam ahead, only broken in the center, there the water piles up and tumbles over in a vast green hump. The launch puts her nose and heaves up her stern as she hits the piled-up water; then she shoots down the slo landing with a crash on the high green waves beneath the  waterfall.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: Green water comes boiling over the port deck and into the boat. Allnutt must hold onto the engine to keep from bein swept off his feet. It seems as though The African Queen doomed to put her nose deeper and deeper into the torrent until she will submerge entirely -- but at the last possi moment she shakes herself loose and comes clear.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: as she throws her weight on the tiller

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Stop the engine!

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he obeys dazedly.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: The maneuver was nicely calculated; the launch's momentum carries her through the edge of the eddy into the slack w under the lip of the dam. She comes up against this natur pier with hardly a bump, and instantly a trembling Allnut is fastening painters to rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew!!!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: as she starts to rise, but finding herself weak in the kn sits back momentarily. Despite an empty feeling in her st and a pounding heart, she wears a smile of satisfaction. She looks around. They are moored in what must be one of loveliest corners of Africa. There are numerous shelves o the high banks bearing flowering plants which trail shimm wreaths down over the rocks. A beam of sunlight reaches o the edge of the gorge and turns its spray into a dancing  shadow. The NOISE of the fall is not deafening, but rathe pleasant musical accompaniment to the joyful SINGING of t river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How lovely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt enters the SHOT from BEHIND CAMERA. She turns her smile on briefly. then raises her eyes again to the hangi gardens above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Lovely, isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following her gaze) It is at that. (he laughs suddenly) We sure pulled it off, didn't we,  Miss? Sucked the Germans in proper.  They were so surprised to see the  ole African Queen -- they didn't  think of shootin' at us till we were  almost past. They didn't believe  anybody'd try to get down these  gorges. Didn't believe nobody could.  Well, we showed 'em, didn't we? (Rose nods) Not that I'd like to do it every day  of the week. We took on enough water  to sink anything else that floats.  He reaches for the pump and goes to  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming out of her  reverie) Here -- let me do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting) Oh, no, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- but don't wear yourself  out... I'll pick up some wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose applies herself to the pump. It takes her a little w to get into the right rhythm, and when she does, even so  small a thing as this brings a thrill of achievement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hardly know what happened after  Shona. Everything's a jumble. I have  no idea how far we've come or whether  it's morning or afternoon or --

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT AND ROSE
dialogues.text: as Allnutt gathers wood on the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you were too busy, Miss, to  pay attention to anything but what  you were doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Did I -- do all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with deep feeling) Better'n all right, Miss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face flushes with pride.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as he goes back onto the boat carrying an armload of wood He is limping a little. He lets the wood fall by the engi then sits down and begins to unlace his canvas shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picked up a thorn on the bank, I  guess. Went right through the rubber  sole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her knees, she slips the shoe off; she takes his slend rather appealing foot into her hands. She finds the place entry of the thorn and presses it with her finger-tips wh Allnutt twitches and jumps with absurd ticklishness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there's nothing there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets his foot go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lingers on the bench, gazing up at the flowers, while  Rose lingers on her knees at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a certain awe in his  tone) It is pretty at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks up at his face. There is something appealing,  almost childlike about the little man as he looks wonderi around. Her expression grows tender; she would like to pe him. He looks down at her. She averts her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reminds me -- that waterfall does --  of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt never tells what it reminds him of. He puts out h hand toward Rose. She catches it -- to hold it, not to pu it away. Allnutt comes down to his knees and they are in  each other's arms.

dialogues.speaker: AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: as a few slanting rays of the sun strike her funnel. Vapo still cling to the surface of the river. Over the SOUND o the waterfall, comes the tuneful SINGING of a bird. Prese Rose's figure is revealed moving about.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: as she pours tea into two cups, and moves with them towar the stern, CAMERA PANNING WITH HER as she crosses to the  sleeping Allnutt. CAMERA MOVES into CLOSE TWO SHOT as she kneels beside Allnutt and puts one tea-cup down close to outstretched hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Mr. Allnutt. I mean -- dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening his eyes) Well now -- blimey! This is more  like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two spoonfuls of sugar is right,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Fancy your building the fire and all --  while I slept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose regards him tenderly for a long moment; then, with a birdlike movement, she kisses him on the cheek. Allnutt p his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear -- there's something I simply  must know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a blushing  interval) What's your first name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself like a  schoolgirl) Charlie... Charlie... Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give us another kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her arms around him,  kissing him) Charlie! Charlie dear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hold each other for a while. Then she slips out of h arms, hands him his cup and they begin stirring their tea Rose looks at the beauty all around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her eyes suddenly  wet) This must be one of the loveliest  places in all Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been around a bit and I must  say I never seen no place to compare  with it in the whole world. Kinda  hate to leave it. (hastily, as though  he fears being  misunderstood) Not that I ain't all for goin' on,  Y'unnerstand. (she gives his hand a  squeeze) Do you spose that last big cataract  coulda been Ulanga Falls? As I  remember the map, it was just a little  way down from Shona. And if it was  Ulanga, there ain't no more big  cataracts between us an' the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much farther is the lake, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- 'bout two 'undred miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are quiet a moment. Abruptly, Rose gets final, and  energetic -- swallows the last of her tea in that manner stands up, a touching blend of spinsterish edginess and  blossoming female softness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose it's time we were on  our way.

dialogues.speaker: DECK OF BOAT
