dialogues.text: Rose takes her place at the tiller and Allnutt goes forwa in unquestioning obedience. He is boss of the family, but she is boss of the boat and the voyage. He casts off, and starts up the engine. Again The African Queen is under wa

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: at the tiller. She looks back, drinking in the place with her eyes. She wants never to forget a single detail. Alln enters the SCENE -- puts his arm around her, and stands  looking back at the loveliest place in the world.

dialogues.speaker: AFT
dialogues.text: We see the waterfall and the flowers withdraw. The SOUND the waterfall still dominates -- a SOUND of serene,  inexhaustible vitality like that of their bloodstream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a broken voice) Give us another kiss, old girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss, as the boat is swept into motion.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: The river is smooth, swift and fairly straight. The launc passes some hippos bathing in the shallows. The deep, swi running channel carries her to within a few yards of the  great beasts. Allnutt and Rose shout at them and wave their arms. The h squeal like pigs. Allnutt imitates the SOUND, a feat whic Rose finds to be funny beyond words. She laughs until it painful and she has to hold her side. Allnutt laughs too, between squeals, hugely delighted with the success of his imitation. Just as Rose is about able to control her laug he squeals once again, which sends her off into fresh pea of mirth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop, Charlie -- stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their laughter begins to die down, then starts up again.  Finally comes a moment of silence while they struggle to  regain breath, and during that moment Allnutt hears a SOU which is not at all funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie, listen... You 'ear wot I 'ear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER the SOUND of the engine, comes a distant ROAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that wasn't Ulanga Falls,  after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt applies himself to the boiler, putting more wood adjusting the draft. The speed of the river increases, as does the DIN of the  approaching cataract. The African Queen begins to heave a the first waves of the race.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: staring forward as she braces herself once more to hold t tiller steady.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIVER AHEAD
dialogues.text: as the waterfall comes into view, Allnutt in f.g. He throws her a swift, backward look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: scared, but game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls) Goodbye, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shouting an answer; his voice is lost in the UPROAR.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: as she rears up and hangs for a moment at the crest of th waterfall. Then she shoots forward and down, finally to c in a tangle of currents below the waterfall. She shakes w the impact. Water flies back, high over the top of the fu then she surges on. There is a TEARING SOUND beneath, followed by a horrid  vibration which seems as if it will shake the boat to pie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams) Keep her going, Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: opening the throttle. The devastating vibration increases

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: as she fights to keep the boat in mid-current, but someth is wrong with the steering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams) Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He points toward the bank where a big rock juts out into river.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: fighting the tiller. The boat swings around crabwise towa the rock, and it looks for a moment as though the stern w surely crash into it. Rose keeps the tiller hard over. Su enough, The African Queen comes all the way about, her bo to the shore, grounded; but the maneuver is not completel successful. Instantly she heels and rolls. A mass of wate comes boiling in over the gunwale. The boiler fire is  extinguished and a wild flurry of steam pours out.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: Grabbing a painter, he leaps like an athlete into the whi eddy, gets his shoulder under the bows and heaves.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: The bows slide off and the boat rights herself, wallowing three-quarters full of water. Instantly the current pulls her downstream. CAMERA PANS as Allnutt leaps up the face of the rock,  clutching the painter. He gives it a turn around an angle the rock and braces himself. His shoulder-joints crack as the rope tightens, but slowly the boat swings in to shore Five seconds later, she is safe, and Allnutt is making pa after painter fast to the shore.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: standing on the bench in the stern, the water slopping at her feet. She manages a smile at Allnutt. She feels a lit sick and faint now that it is all over.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He sits down on a rock and grins back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We nearly done it that time, didn't  we, Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: as she sits on the gunwale. She doesn't wish to let her  weakness be seen. She forces herself to be matter of fact

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how much we've lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get this water out and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings himself aboard, splashes down to the waist and  fishes about for the pails.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: as she tucks her skirt up into her underclothes as though she were a little girl at the seaside. CAMERA PANS with h to Allnutt. She takes a pail and the two of them go to  bailing, and conversation ceases with the effort.

dialogues.speaker: SHOULDER
dialogues.text: He has gotten up a couple of floor boards in the waist, a is down on his knees inspecting the planking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better than we coulda hoped  for. We 'aven't lost nothin', far as  I can see. 'Aven't damaged 'er skin  worth mentionin'. I shoulda thought  there'd been an 'ole in 'er  somewheres, after wot she's been  through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was all that clattering just  before we stopped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still got to find that out, old  girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we going to do that, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll 'ave to go underneath and 'ave  a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is out of his shirt and trousers in a jiffy. His drawe are the old-fashioned kind reaching to the knee and tying with a string behind. He picks up a rope and ties one end around his middle and gives the other end to Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ain't no other way. You stay  'andy with that rope -- case there's  a fancy current down at the bottom...  'Ere goes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And over the side he goes. His feet remain in view for a  moment; then, kicking, they disappear.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROPELLER SHAFT OF THE LAUNCH
dialogues.text: Allnutt swims into the picture, giving forth with bubbles He inspects the shaft.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: leaning far over the stern, trying to glimpse what is  happening beneath The African Queen. Presently, Allnutt's head breaks the surface of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hovering anxiously  over him) Could you see anything, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT AND ROSE
dialogues.text: With her help, he climbs back aboard, sits down on the be Rose sits beside him and waits for him to regain his brea She puts out her dry hand and clasps his wet one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dully) Shaft's bent to blazes like a  corkscrew, and there's a blade gone  off the prop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to mend it, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mend it! (he laughs bitterly) Not likely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that, dear? (he doesn't answer) What shall we have to do before we  go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell ya. (savage despondency  in his tone) I'll tell ya what we could do if we  was sittin' in the landin' slip at  Limbasi. We could pull this old tub  out an' take the shaft down an' 'aul  it over to the workshop where they'd  forge it straight again. An' then we  could write to the makers and get a  new prop. They might 'ave one in  stock 'cause this boat ain't over  thirty years old. An' while we was  waitin' we might clean 'er bottom  an' paint 'er. Then we could put in  the shaft an' the new prop an' launch  'er an' go on as if nothin' 'ad  'appened. -- But this ain't Limbasi,  an' so we can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Can't you get the shaft out without  pulling the boat on shore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. I might. Means workin'  underwater. Could do it perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you were able to get the  shaft up on shore, could you  straighten it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't got no hearth. Ain't got no  anvil. Ain't got no coal. Ain't got  nothin'. An' furthermore, I ain't no  blacksmith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping her memory) I saw a Masai native working once.  Using charcoal... on a big hollow  stone. He had a boy to fan the  charcoal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I've seen that, too! But I'd  use a bellows, myself -- make them  easy enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you think that would be  better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the engineer in him  taking over) There's 'eaps an' 'eaps of driftwood  up on the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you try it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly shying) No. It ain't no use, Rosie, old girl.  I was forgettin' that prop. There's  a blade gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we go on the blades that are  left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a torque. Prop wouldn't be  balanced. Wouldn't take five minutes  for the shaft to be like a corkscrew  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to make another blade.  There's lots of iron and stuff you  could use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironically) And tie it on, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (missing his irony) Yes, if you think that will do. But  wouldn't it be better to -- weld it?  That's the right word, isn't it?  Weld it on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a one, Rosie. Really you are. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't weld the right word, dear? You  know what I mean even if it isn't,  don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's the right word, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs again. At first, Rose is afraid that his laugh caused by desperation, but when she sees that it is not, laughs with him. Directly they are in each other's arms, kissing as two pe might be expected to kiss on the second day of their  honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: working on the shaft. Now and then he bangs his hammer on the hull of the boat. Apparently he and Rose have a syste of signals. Just as he succeeds in loosening the bracket  supporting the shaft, a whim of the river expresses itsel in a fierce underwater swirl. Allnutt is turned upside do but he holds onto the bracket like grim death.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: pulling in on the rope. Allnutt comes to the surface, dro the bracket into the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping) Swallered about half the river that  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were down there an awfully long  time. I got scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaft is ready to come out now. It'll  be too heavy for me to swim up with.  I'll 'ave to walk with it in to  shore... Well, 'ere goes -- for the  last time, I 'ope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ow do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to peel off her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wot d'you think you're goin' to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go down with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' get drownded? You don't know wot  it's like, Rosie. Them currents is  just fierce. (he shakes his head) Wot'll you be thinkin' of next! (he takes two deep  breaths) Well, 'ere goes. (After a third and  deeper breath, he is  gone.)

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWATER
dialogues.text: Allnutt swims into view, slides the shaft out through the bearings and begins to carry it toward shore. The current catches him. He loses his footing, regains it, only to fa again. The heavy shaft is too much for one man to handle. He is struggling vainly with it when into the SCENE swims Rose. She takes one end of the shaft, Allnutt the other, together they walk under water toward shore

dialogues.speaker: MAKESHIFT FORGE
dialogues.text: Rose is working the bellows while Allnutt hammers patient Presently he lays aside the hammer and, using a taut stri judges the straightness of the shaft. Apparently he is pl with his work, for he grins at Rose and nods briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If my old dad 'ad put me to  blacksmithin' when I was a kid, I  don't think I should never 'ave come  to Africa. I might've -- (a faraway look comes  into his eyes; he is  thinking about Charing  Cross on a Saturday  night; finally he  shakes himself) -- But then I shouldn't never 'ave  met you, Rosie old girl. (he goes back to  hammering) I wouldn't trade you for all the  fried fish shops in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting this  accolade) Oh, Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips a ring of wire over the end of the shaft and mov it up and down its length, testing the diameter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) Well, I guess it's just about as  good as I can get it -- And it didn't  take so long a time, neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blade's a different proposition.  I'll 'ave to make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: held in place on stone anvil with a pair of pliers; it is beginning to take shape under blows of Allnutt's hammer. pliers carry it over the other two blades, which are its  models, and turn it this way and that for purposes of  comparison.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT AND ROSE
dialogues.text: getting the shaft, with its new propeller, back into posi

dialogues.speaker: THE PROPELLER, (UNDER WATER)
dialogues.text: turning. SOUND of the engine, o.s. CAMERA TILTS UP. Allnu is leaning over the stern, watching. In the b.g. stands R with her hand on the throttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It turns right enough. But that don't  prove nothin' much. Will it stand up  under a full head of steam, that's  the question. We'll get our answer  out there -- and Lord 'elp us if it  ain't the right one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's find out right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: Rose comes back and takes the tiller in hand. Allnutt cas off the moorings. As the bows come out into the current, gently opens the throttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends over the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither she nor Allnutt hears the other; neither is meant to; there is a high courage in them both.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS with boat as she surges out into the stream. spins around as her bows come into the river, and Rose pu the tiller across. Next moment she is flying down the str once more.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: In the foreground, a spray of jungle foliage in sharp and exotic contrast to the upland pines of the last sequence. The African Queen comes into view, and CAMERA PANS with h A flock of ibis in the path of The African Queen rise on  great snowy wings, only to settle again when she has pass

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT AND ROSE
dialogues.text: looking about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we done it, old girl. We got  down the rapids all right. I didn't  think it could be done. If it 'adn't  been for you, sweetheart, we shouldn't  be 'ere now. Don't you feel proud of  yourself, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) No, of course not. Look at the way  you made the engine go. Look how you  mended the propeller. It wasn't me  at all. (with even greater  emphasis) I don't think there's another man  alive who could have done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) I don't think anyone's likely to  try.

dialogues.speaker: A TURN IN THE RIVER
dialogues.text: Her waters widen and a dreary, marshy, amphibious world i revealed; tree trunks and little creeper-entangled island take the place of the foaming rocks of the upper river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like this old river got tired  of all that runnin' an' jumpin' she  did an' decided to lay down an' rest  for a while... 'Ow about our doin'  the same, Rosie -- seein' as 'ow the  sun's goin' down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose nods. She edges The African Queen in towards the sho Allnutt gets his boat hook into the stump of a large tree which, still half alive, grows precariously on the edge o the water with half its roots exposed. Rose goes to the boiler and starts making tea, while Alln gets a line around a root. There is hardly any current. T light is fading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be right 'bout 'ere the river  changes her nyme from Ulanga to Bora. (he slaps at a mosquito) Not that it matters. Nobody lives  between 'ere and the lake. Unless  you call monkeys people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps again. There is the high frequency SOUND of  mosquitoes which fill the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping) How much farther do you think it is  to the lake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- not so many miles, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps his arms and legs, get up and stands and makes s passes in the air, as though shadow-boxing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping) But what, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a note of hysteria  in his voice) I got a feelin' that before long  we'll wish we was shootin' the rapids  again... Ow!... Ow!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: It is nightfall and the mosquitoes have left their homes the mud, under leaves, on stalks of reeds, to hunt flesh blood. They close in on Rose and Allnutt; they bite throu clothes -- they crawl under clothes; some of the smallest creep into nostrils and under eyelids. Rose and Allnutt a used to ordinary attacks, but this is beyond all experien They slap ever more wildly; they begin to show panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is awful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling at her dress) I'm going in! I'm going to get under  the water!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! That's it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But looking past Rose toward the river, he sees something that makes him grab her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm being eaten alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) Look.

dialogues.speaker: LARGE CROCODILE
dialogues.text: on the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) What'd you say 'bout bein' eaten  alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we see that it is not one crocodile but several  submerged and partially submerged. Two slide into the wat from the bank.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: After their first start at the sight of the crocs, they g back to fighting the cloud of mosquitoes that, hungry for blood, fill the air with their WHINING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me out of here, Charlie! I'm  going mad!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: Allnutt runs to the engine, tries to start it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't no steam. Can't start engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wails) I can't stand it, Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ere! Lay down! Get under the canvas  there! I'll get us out into the  channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She obeys. Allnutt casts off, and seizing a deckboard beg to paddle. The space between the launch and the bank slow widens till at last they are in the channel. Rose peeps o from under the canvas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Rosie. We got away from 'em.  You can come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crawling out) I'm ashamed, Charlie, acting like  that -- but I couldn't help it. I  was going mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so bitten!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even in the faded light, his face and body show innumerab bumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bites themselves ain't so bad;  it's 'avin' them all round you. I've  'eard of them sendin' buffaloes an'  native cattle stark starin' mad --  an' they run an' run till they fall  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) What are we going to do, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're asking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will they be like that wherever we  tie up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't just drift all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the river keeps straight an' deep  an' slow, there ain't nothin' much  can 'urt us -- I know! I'll let the  anchor out a ways. She'll stop us  before trouble gets too near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets the anchor chain out, then sits on the bench. Ros leans against him. He puts his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long silence) What a time, Rosie -- what a time!  We'll never lack for stories to tell  our grandchildren -- if we live to  'ave any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The launch seems to be floating in space, solitary as any one of the stars that are now beginning to shine and twin overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river ends in a five-mile-wide pool, fringed all the round with reeds. These reeds extend as far as the eye ca see. The boat comes down into the pool, nosing along the edge, looking for an opening. Allnutt and Rose are talking as s steers and he feeds the furnace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- maybe that's a channel. (it isn't) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A herd of hippopotami suddenly surface and scatter. Plung through water, mud and reeds just ahead of the boat. Behi them is left a faint indication of a channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about there? (pointing) That looks like a way through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: showing a very doubtful passage into the reed bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be. (worried) I dunno. (pause) Once we get in, an' these 'ere reeds  close up be'ind our stern -- we'd  never get back, you know, Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't stay going round and round  out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anything goes wrong a few 'undred  feet in there, we're 'eld in a trap,  you know -- till we starve or go orf  our 'eads. I dunno! (loudly. decisively) All right. Put 'er over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose swings the tiller and the boat charges at the little opening in the reeds.

dialogues.speaker: REEDS
dialogues.text: looking from outside. We see the boat nose into the openi In front of her the reeds part. Others are pressed under  water. But as soon as her full length is inside, the reed she has parted or submerged close together again, or rise slowly from under water. As they close, they form an  increasingly solid barrier behind her wide stern. Very so The African Queen is completely hidden from us except for the top of her tall funnel, which moves more and more slo as she goes on into the reed bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: seen from a few feet above. A view of the endless miles o papyrus reed. At one place we see the top of the funnel o The African Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the engine choking and gasping, shaking the launch. CAMER

dialogues.speaker: BOW OF LAUNCH
dialogues.text: pushing ineffectually against the knotted roots of the re which have piled up under it. There is almost no water -- just the tangled roots and an inch of liquid mud.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: shutting off steam. The corners of his mouth tighten. He badly frightened. He tries to keep the fear out of his vo as he tells Rose; but we can see that Rose is desperately scared too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the propeller, I think. It won't  work in this mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt looks down over stern. He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the boat-'ook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt finding boat hook and moving forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can pull 'er along.

dialogues.speaker: BOWS OF LAUNCH
dialogues.text: Allnutt reaching forward with boat hook, hooking it into  strong clumps of reeds, pulling desperately. The clumps  resist; it seems as if the boat is about to move. Then th clumps give way.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: amidships, watching Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here! Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds a long pole or plank, chooses a good spot and b to push. After a couple of ineffectual attempts, Allnutt  hooks an especially strong clump at the same time as Rose finds a solid spot against which to push. The boat heaves and shakes, and, with a final heart-break effort on the part of Rose and Allnutt, it moves forward couple of feet.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: gasping for breath, hope flickering up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they resume their efforts, CAMERA DRAWS BACK, RISING T

dialogues.speaker: REED BED
dialogues.text: from twenty feet above. We see the funnel of the launch  inching slowly and painfully through the reeds.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: in the reeds. Rose and Allnutt are poling with their boat hooks. Even through the masks of mud they are wearing, we can see that they are both terribly haggard and exhausted

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've come along under steam, and we  paddled an' pushed 'an' pulled the  ole boat along with the 'ook. Wot we  ain't done yet is get out an' carry  'er. I spose that'll come next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to breathe! -- the air is so  wet and heavy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't 'ardly tell water from land --  or for that matter, day from night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing is like a fever dream,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the channels we've lost -- an'  the twistin' we've done -- we may  come back out where we started -- if  we come out at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've always followed the current,  dear -- what little there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't mean nothin' -- with this  river. This river's crazy. Crazy as  I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Charlie. (she touches him) We must try to keep hold of ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, old girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt starts pushing all the more energetically on his  pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best thing to put the roses back in  our cheeks is to get out o' these  reeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt's exertions carry them into the shallows. The boa touches bottom. Not all of their strivings with the boath serve to move it an inch further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) What I said a while back about 'avin'  to carry the boat was meant for a  joke -- but as it turns out, I wasn't  jokin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking the painter, he goes over the side and starts pull like a draft animal. Slowly, ever so slowly, the boat beg to move, until at last she is floating again. Rose helps him back in. Suddenly she gives a cry of horri surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose can only point. As he sees what it is, Allnutt's fac contorts with panic and disgust. He makes a kind of growl horrified surprise, across which:

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT'S ARM, CHEST OR BELLY
dialogues.text: A couple of leeches hang to him, visibly swelling with hi blood. QUICK PULL AWAY TO TWO SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT -- Over h line; we see 20 or 30 leeches on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Augh, the little beggars -- (a cracking voice) Pull 'em off me, Rosie -- no, the  heads stay -- poison yer blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden remembrance) Salt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes to get their tin box of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eyes on what she is doing below SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: DETAIL
dialogues.text: applied to a leech. It flinches, elongates, bunches and  swells, and drops off.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: She dabs salt on the last two or three, while he stands l a partly calmed, still shocked horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anythin' I hate in this world it's  leeches -- filthy devils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands trembling quietly, the triangular bites still b freely. Rose dabs tenderly at one of the sinister little  wounds.

dialogues.speaker: FROM STERN
dialogues.text: They hook the boat with great effort slowly along. The hu grazes something. They work still harder. There is a rumb SCRAPE. Then, also, a sludgy GRINDING. With the grinding, Allnutt moans as if in his sleep and t desperately to reverse direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping) Back! 'Old 'er back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating him) Mud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is too much momentum for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reversing his dragging) Let's try an' get 'er over it, then.  Give 'er all you got, Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They strain enough to half kill them; the sludgy grinding intensifies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping) Good girl -- we're still makin'  'eadway -- All you got now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly the boat comes to a dead stop.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOTIONLESS GUNWALE AND MANGROVES
dialogues.text: and the just perceptibly moving slime on the water betwee

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: They sit by each other, she holding his forehead; he is i dry nausea of exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, there, dear. There, there.  There, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Able to speak, ashamed, he tries to joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine specimen of a man I am, ain't  I!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the bravest man that ever  lived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is silent, slowly and rather inanely shaking his head; she watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a very old wife  to a very old husband) Lie down, dear. Rest. Both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps on shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just overdo, that's all. You  must take care of yourself! You're  not one bit well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well! We're both of us half dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring this) Besides, it's high time we had our  supper. It'll be dark before long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You 'ave some. I ain't up to it yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a nice steaming cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fix yourself some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just yet, thank you. (she gets up, taking  his hand) Come now. (she helps him weakly  up) Lie-down.

dialogues.speaker: VERTICAL TWO SHOT --
dialogues.text: Rose helps Allnutt to the floor, and nurse-like, puts bun rags under his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There now. All comfy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You rest, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed I will. (she lies down beside  him and smiles at  him) That's all we need, a good long rest,  and we'll be on our way in a jiffy.  You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (managing a smile) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns her back to him because she can't meet his eyes Both lie with eyes wide open, obsessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Try to sleep, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Sure. You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches a hand behind her and pets him. He clearly ha and resists, an impulse to take her hand. She withdraws her hand. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; with quiet  dread) Yes, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know the truth, don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; very quietly) I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes show deep pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if we had all our strength we'd  never be able to get her off this  mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a chance in this world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are silent a while; everything is in their eyes. As  suddenly and swiftly as her weakness allows, she turns to him; their faces are close. CAMERA DROPS NEARER. She looks into his quiet eyes; her own eyes are fiery, no with tears but with passionate, incredulous despair;  speechless, trying to speak; a sort of palsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So useless!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts a hand along her cheek. Slowly he realizes, and  enhances for us, her only concern with dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't come no better'n you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lie still, looking at each other. Within about 15 seconds, their faces profoundly alter; by changes of makeup, every couple of seconds, the motionles faces become years older, and take on a kind of worn maje and gradually lose consciousness; by the end of the secon the eyes are closed. The CAMERA meanwhile very slowly  withdraws upward. In the last we can clearly see of their faces, they are quite possibly dead. As CAMERA RISES, we them at full length, as prostrated and flattened as grass pressed in a book; then, their static boat and the crawli water; the CAMERA RISES among the overhanging mangrove  branches which obscure and trap them; and, as it rises, t SCREEN slowly darkens. The CAMERA STOPS RISING. The dead silence is broken by an infinitesimal SOUND OF RUSTLING. By eye and ear, after a seconds, it becomes recognizable as the stillest, slender kind of rain, splintering downward, very gradually increa in volume and in richness of SOUND as the darkness deepen to an immense, peaceful, steady, flooding downpour. The  darkness pales into full daylight and the downpour contin and through it we can dimly see the boat and the prostrat bodies, and after perhaps ten seconds of the new daylight (after maybe fifteen of darkness), the rain begins to aba and the CAMERA BEGINS VERY SLOWLY TO DESCEND. It gets down through the branches. The bodies are motionl so is the boat; but the slime on the water, though still  slow, moves with a distinct new kind of energy. THE CAMERA STOPS DESCENDING. A couple of seconds later, t boat stirs, just perceptibly; motionless again; then stir again, more distinctly. At height of PULL UP OF CAMERA and darkening, a quiet ric CRUMPLING OF THUNDER. (Throughout this short sequence all sounds, even those recorded at full blast, are held way d on the track -- as if heard in a dream or in imagination. Across MUTTERING OF THUNDER --

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: Low in foreground, a sharp watershed peak; all foliage is fiercely ruffled, showing pale undersides: beyond, a  tremendous valley, a dim streak of river through it; beyo that, magnificent peaks: but most of the SCREEN is sky, i which (sped up by SLOW CAMERA) prodigious black and white clouds bloom, explode and wrestle. Over all, a solemn, om light. A moment of absolute stillness; then first huge dr of splattering rain; then SCREEN is blinded and deafened  with simultaneous THUNDER AND LIGHTNING, over which CAMER TILTS DOWNWARD along the line of enormous columns of rain which take over SCREEN. SHOOTING UPSTREAM, to breadth of a swollen river, in heav rain: PAN DOWNSTREAM, past Mission clearing. Possible CUT IN: Mission bungalow screen door flapping an banging in wind; or porch rocking chairs' ghostlike cradl PAN ON DOWNSTREAM flooding water. LONG SHOT across roaring river on Shona, PANNING DOWNSTRE one tiny figure struggles miserably through mud: Possible CUT IN: the drowned German flag, clinging  disconsolately to its pole. END PAN on water at mouth of rapids; bring up ROAR From h and to one side: where the rapids enter the Basin: (great augmented water NOISE.) PULL CAMERA DOWN and to right to VERTICAL SHOT over the R Allnutt waterfall, much more water than before, plunging  into pool; bringing up SOUND sharp. TILT CAMERA UP to right, to center on where rapids leave pool; the whole pool, dark and calm on first trip, is now boiling white. TILT A LITTLE FURTHER and CUT OFF SHORT. The rock behind which they sheltered for the welding; it so over-whelmed with water it is no longer visible; there could be no anchorage here now. QUICK PAN DOWNSTREAM. Where the river enters the pre-Delta broadening: the wate is markedly slowed, but there is much more movement than  when we were here before; TILT UPWARD across a solid floo of calmer, rain-marked water, lighter rain and THUNDER,  overcast; SOUND of calm, steady rain on miles of water; t reeds where Rose and Allnutt entered: lighter rain; its S among reeds; the water is distinctly higher on the reeds broken reeds distinctly move on it; LIFT towards mangrove past reeds. Mangroves and shadow; and the infinitesimal splintery  whisperings of light rain. TILT CAMERA DOWNWARD and resum the vertical SHOT on which we faded from Rose and Allnutt and SLOWLY BRING THE CAMERA TOWARDS THEM, through and bey mangrove tanglings, to MEDIUM CLOSE. The boat shines with wetness and they are drabbled with it. Nothing moves exce the slime-flecked water and that moves slowly, but with a new kind of energy. Neither Rose nor Allnutt is conscious At MEDIUM CLOSE, halt CAMERA. A couple of seconds after i stops, there is a first, scarcely discernible shifting mo of the boat. They are still unconscious. Bring up the SMA SOUNDS OF RUNNING WATER a little; another little shifting the boat; a little more distinct. They are still unconsci

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She looks as if she had cried herself dry, and she looks if she might quite possibly be dead.

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: His face is crumpled and distorted against one elbow; in face, too, there is the look of incredible sadness and de and he, too, could be dead. (In both faces, also the epitome of utter weariness and o rest after weariness.) DETAIL SHOT -- Allnutt's emaciated hand, motionless, care her shoulder, and involved in her hair. ANOTHER -- Her own hands, motionless; they are folded --  quite unconsciously -- in her automatic gesture of prayer TILT CAMERA UPWARDS from this -- past gunwale, we see by  quiet motion of mangrove roots, that the whole boat is  cradling gently in the rain. FROM BENEATH BOAT -- DETAIL SHOT -- past bottom of hull, daylight opens just discernibly as boat lifts from muck.

dialogues.speaker: PAST PROW
dialogues.text: Prow is just perceptibly rising.

dialogues.speaker: BENEATH THE KEEL
dialogues.text: a real, gaping light now, visible in motion of boat and o water and of muck-flakes in water.

dialogues.speaker: PAST PROW
dialogues.text: The prow really moves forward now.

dialogues.speaker: PAST PROW, (UNDERWATER)
dialogues.text: A new obstruction looms; a thick, dark root; prow (and CA come right up against it but hit it slowly, a little to o side, and the whole boat, with a hollow SCRAPING, glances along past.

dialogues.speaker: BOAT, (FROM DOWNSTREAM)
dialogues.text: silently floating towards CAMERA in rustling rain, pointi slantwise, beginning to straighten.

dialogues.speaker: ABOARD
dialogues.text: who are still unconscious; athwart the boat; the quiet  movement past the mangroves.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENGINE
dialogues.text: The engine approaches a low and dangerous-looking branch; just clears

dialogues.speaker: BOAT
dialogues.text: The boat nears a splitting of waterways. Both look bad, b one looks far worse; prow nudges a mangrove mass and for few seconds everything is at stalemate; then stern begins swing forward.

dialogues.speaker: BOAT STERN
dialogues.text: as it begins to swing forward. It looks as if everything  would jam; and with soft bumpings and subdued underwater  scrapings and near-misses above water too, the boat does slow, somnambulistic broken-field crawl during which the  light becomes stronger and the rain less, and its SOUND l

dialogues.speaker: ALLNUTT AND ROSE
dialogues.text: The strengthened lights and shadows move on their faces a their closed eyes. Rose registers nothing. Allnutt's face and his slow, weak, negative hands both convey that he is dreaming something and doesn't believe it. His face goes  inert again. There are fewer shadows now, brighter light, and there is a deep quiet scraping SOUND which makes him  open his eyes. Still unable to believe what he sees, he t his face up toward CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: MANGROVES
dialogues.text: and the sun-touched last of the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s., softly; an  almost incapable  voice) Rose. Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: He is half-up, hands on her, trying to stroke and pat her awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling. Dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her head gently between his hands and turns her  face up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at us, Rosie! My God just look!  We're movin', dear! We're movin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her eyes and looks up. All she sees at first is Allnutt's face, close to her. She looks at it with devoti and with terrible sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did our best, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs her quite roughly into his arms and kisses her  several times, rapidly and without passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking through this) No, look, Rosie, just look at us!  We're movin', don't you see? Movin',  that's what!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with this, as we catch her first realization and reac we leave the last of the mangroves and are among the reed gliding slowly yet freely; with a RUSTLING of reeds again the boat reminiscent of the rustling of the finished rain and the late afternoon sunlight moving through the reeds though they were harpstrings, and casting an almost rustl of slender light and shadow across their faces. Her face  becomes quietly transcendent. She gets with great difficu to her feet (she is very weak; so is he) and, reaching ov the gunwale, begins grabbing reeds and with what strength she has, tries to help them along. As soon as he realizes he gets up weakly, too, and hurries and gets the pole, cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, Rosie dear! You just rest, old  girl. Easy now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, with what strength he has, he is poling. Past them and past prow, we see light beyond the high ree which steadily, slowly part for the prow and sweep past t flanks of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: Both continue working; their incredulous eyes are fixed p the prow. Behind them, reeds partly close back, dark mang recede. Their eyes intensify.

dialogues.speaker: PAST PROW
dialogues.text: The last few feet of the reeds part and the boat drifts f and clear onto a horizonless floor of golden light (or if black and white, a kind of unearthly silver); a low group wooded islands in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIUM CLOSE
dialogues.text: as they still drift, a soft breeze on them, looking aroun He sits down, obviously because he feels too weak to stan Rose, still standing, looks towards him, waiting his auth to believe what she already knows. They speak quietly, as someone were asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It -- really is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches out his hand to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- sit down, old girl. Yer  tremblin' like a leaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she gets down quietly onto her knees and bows her hea He looks at her a few moments, then a little uneasily and shyly, gets down onto his knees. She begins to cry very d and silently; we don't see her face. Allnutt puts his arm around her, and she hides her face against him and cries, audibly now but quietly, taking his free hand in her own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly) There, there, Rosie. There, old girl.  We're all right now, dear. There,  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By Allnutt's face, it is better than that, but he knows w she means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a queer voice) God let us live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musta been 'Im, all right -- 'tweren't  nothin' in our power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet, charged voice) It wasn't for our sakes, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; carefully) 'Ow you mean, Rosie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brought us here to do His work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets to her feet and walks past CAMERA towards bow. ROSE -- (PAST BOW) as she comes up, Allnutt following. Sh is looking all around, and past her we see only empty wat and empty sky. She begins to look impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Rosie, this lake's an 'undred miles  long; forty wide, at the biggest. It  might be days afore she comes our  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then start the fire. We'll go find  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Rosie, we won't 'ave to go out  of our way. She'll come to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrolin' the lake. She's bound to  come by, don't you never worry. An'  when she does, we want to be well  'id.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm. Perhaps you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I am. So let's just cruise about  a bit till we find a good 'idin'  place, an' then we'll lay in wait  fer 'er. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go back towards engine. TWO SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT as, Rose watching almost wit reverence, Allnutt strikes a match and touches it to the  carefully prepared wood.

dialogues.speaker: THEY WATCH
dialogues.text: THE CURLING SMOKE -- (FROM THEIR VIEWPOINT) and catching  flame and the SOUNDS -- an image almost of resurrection. ROSE AND ALLNUTT -- (FROM FIRE'S ANGLE) their faces  revitalizing, as light of flame works on them over increa SOUND of fire; he gently shuts the furnace door, and adju the draft; the fire begins a really happy ROARING. Allnut looks up and around across the water, clearly figuring wh they might cruise around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring) Let's -- see. We might, uh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes sharpen into great intentness on something very  distant. All of a sudden he picks up a bailing pail, dips it full, and douses the fire. TWO SHOT -- ROSE (PAST ALLNUTT) Rose looks at him amazed. gestures silently with a jerk of his head. She walks towa CAMERA and looks. LONG SHOT -- THE LAKE Almost invisibly small on the horiz a small black smudge, a gleaming white speck, which sharp like a fresh star as we look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) That's The Louisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT He gets up on the gunwale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's The Louisa all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way are they going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're comin' this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forcing herself to  be calm) They mustn't see us here. Can we get  far enough among the reeds for them  not to see us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to work fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling and tugging with the boat hooks, they swing the l around and head her into the reeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to cut some down. How  deep is the mud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knife in hand, Allnutt goes over the bows among the reeds WIDER SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT as he goes over the bows. sinks in the mud until the surface of the water is up to armpits. Floundering about, he cuts every reed within rea Then, pulling on the bow painter, he is able to work the  launch up into the cleared space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's still a bit of her sticking  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws a desperate glance towards The Louisa, which i making good time, and is less than half the former distan away. Allnutt splashes back among the reeds and goes on cutting and hauling. Rose helps him to get back on board. He is i state of near collapse from his exertions. He lies on the deck panting while Rose cranes her neck over the reeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) She's coming right toward us, Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT Groaning, Allnutt staggers his knees, then to his feet. Together they watch the appr of The Louisa. LONG SHOT -- THE LOUISA white, spotless, beautiful. At he stern floats the flag of the Imperial German Navy. On her foredeck, we can pick out the six-pound gun which gives t Germans command of the lake. We can see the figures of sa moving about on the deck. Over the SOUND of her engines comes a smartly given order following which The Louisa alters her course by a point o two. CLOSE SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT Allnutt groans again, this time from relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going a different way now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they'd seen us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- THE LOUISA heading toward some little island in the middle of the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're makin' for them islands to  anchor for the night. They'll go on  in the mornin'. But don't you worry.  They'll come 'ere again. You just  see if they don't. You know 'ow  Germans are; they lays down systems  an' they sticks to 'em. Mondays  they're at one place. Tuesdays  somewheres else. Wednesdays p'raps  they're 'ere. Same ole round, week  after week. You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- THE LOUISA as the SOUND of her engines cease

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Look! Wot did I tell ya! She's  droppin' 'er anchor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) How long will it take to get the  torpedoes ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get the stuff into the tubes  in no time, as you might say. Don't  know 'bout the detonators. Gotta  make them up, you see -- devise  something. Then we got to cut 'oles  in the bows. Might 'ave it all done  in three days. Depends on them  detonators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose receives this information in silence. Her eyes remai on The Louisa, now lying at anchor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie, old girl -- Rosie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a faraway note in  her voice) Yes, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know wot you're thinkin' 'bout  doin'. (he takes her hand  and presses it) You're thinkin' 'bout takin' The  African Queen out at night next time  The Louisa comes 'ere, ain't you,  old girl? (Rose nods) We ought to manage it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN SHOT -- ALLNUTT'S HAND as it takes one of the package out of the box and carries it to one of the cylinders and places it inside. A wrench and the cylinder head are in v lying on the deck. Allnutt's face comes into the SCREEN. He puts more packag into the cylinder. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Allnutt and Rose in TWO SHOT Leaning over the side, Rose brings up handfuls of mud fro the bottom and dumps it on the deck. Allnutt carries the  sticky stuff to the cylinder and drops it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: A DISC OF WOOD IN ALLUTT'S HAND. Three holes have been punched through it. Allnutt's fingers fit cartridges into them. Then a second disc of the same diameter is pla over the first. The second disc has three nails in it. It turned so that a nail point rests on the percussion cap o each cartridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Ought to work all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to screw the pair of discs together. CAMERA PUL BACK revealing Rose and Allnutt intent upon his handiwork

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't put them into the cylinders  yet. They're a bit tricky. We can  put 'em in when we're all ready to  start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be dark then, of course.  Will you be able to do it in the  dark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Case of have to... (he puts the detonators  away in the locker) Better get the cylinders into place  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Rose's help he drags and pushes one of the cylinders forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- THE BOW The cylinders in position, projecti like cannon through two holes on either side of the stem  just above the waterline. o.s., the SOUND of hammering. The CAMERA RAISES and DOLLIES FORWARD TO: CLOSE SHOT --  ALLNUTT -- SHOOTING at him over Rose's shoulder. He is na the cylinders solidly into position with battens torn fro provision cases. Finally, the work done to his satisfacti he tosses the hammer aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, old girl -- I done it all now.  Everything. We're all ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a solemn moment. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reminiscently) You know I been thinkin'. There ain't  no need for us both to -- to do it.  Now I've 'ad time to study it, I can  plainly see it's a one-man job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't be more right, Charlie  dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad you agree, Rosie. When the time  comes I'll put you ashore on the  south side of the lake and you wait  for me while I attend to The Louisa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Certainly not! You're the one to be  put ashore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, you. This whole thing was  my idea, wasn't it?... I'm the logical  one to carry it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Rose! I'm surprised! You're a  very sensible woman as a rule. Now  we won't 'ave no more talk along  those lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can manage this launch every bit  as well as you, Charlie Allnutt, and  you know it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie, you're cracked!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I steer going down the rapids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you steered well enough. But you  don't know nothin' about the engine.  Spose she broke down on you out there  in the middle of the lake? Where  would you be? But me, I'd leave the  tiller and go and do a thing or two  to the engine -- you know, spit on  'er or kick 'er in the belly -- an'  she'd go right to work again. She  knows 'oo 'er boss is, you bet, that  ole engine does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defeated) All right, Charlie. I guess you have  to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now, that's more like it. I'll  dive off a second or two before the  crash and swim over to where you'll  be waitin' on the north shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need of our pretending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know wot you're talkin' about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes you do. There's got to be a  hand on that tiller right up to the  last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt would like to protest; he opens his mouth to do s but no words issue. He falls into a stricken silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't you understand, dear? I wouldn't  care about going on to Nairobi --  without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having no words, Allnutt can only nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) We'll do it together. It will be you  at the engine and me at the tiller,  as it has been from the start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a choked voice) Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you come to think of it, we're  a very lucky couple, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make The African Queen as clean  as we can. Let's scrub her decks and  polish her brass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in quick agreement) I've got a can o' paint for 'er mast.  She ought to look 'er best. 'Er very  best. Representin' as she does the  Royal Navy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT -- THE AFRICAN QUEEN Quite a transformation h taken place in her appearance. Her decks are clean, her b polished. Rose is engaged in painting her stumpy mast. He old boiler shines like a mirror. In fact, Allnutt is usin it as such while he shaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (between strokes of  the razor) I wish I 'ad somethin' clean to put  on. It don't seem right for the ship's  captain to be without pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a pair you can wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean a pair o' yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're the one'll have to look  at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives them to him. Getting into them, Allnutt begins laugh. When he reveals himself to Rose, it is with obviou embarrassment. He assumes a position rather like Septembe Morn's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Put this on, too. (she displays one of  her singlets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't that goin' a bit too far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes it and puts it on. He looks intently at Rose,  expecting ridicule. Her eyes are not on him; they are on horizon. LONG SHOT -- A PUFF OF SMOKE AND A WHITE DOT The Louisa. TWO SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT as she stares at the horizon His eyes follow hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- A CYLINDER -- (NIGHT) as Allnutt's hands fi fitting a detonator into its fore-end, tapping around its edges with a hammer. He is in the water. CAMERA PANS with him around the bow to the other cylinder. Rose passes dow the second detonator. Allnutt puts it into place and pull himself up over the side. He goes to the boiler which cas a red glow on the surrounding deck, and inspects the gaug Steam is up. He looks across the waters of the lake towar the little group of islands. LONG SHOT -- THE LOUISA A bundle of faint lights in the  distance. TWO SHOT -- ROSE AND ALLNUTT as a sudden gust of wind str the surrounding reeds, causing them to bend and toss. All takes Rose in his arms. Clinging to one another, they kis try to speak; fail -- then separate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blowing up a bit. We better get  started. All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unfastens the side painter, then takes the boat hook a thrusts it against a clump of reeds. The African Queen mo slowly out into the fairway. Allnutt lays the boat hook d feels for the throttle valve and opens it. The propeller  begins its beat and the engine its muffled clanking. FULL SHOT -- THE AFRICAN QUEEN coming out of the reeds in the lake. TWO SHOT -- ALLNUTT AND ROSE Allnutt is staring at the bo scowling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (observes his  expression with  anxiety) Is something the matter, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Er bows are ridin' awful low for  this kind o' water. Them 'eavy  cylinders are what's doin' it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wave splashes over the bows into the boat, so that her  decks swim in water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to get 'er nose way up 'igh or  we'll be in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins shifting ballast into the stern of the boat, wh is swaying and staggering about in haphazard fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been through worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rivers is one thing -- open water  another. She ain't built for it. Not  when it's rough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the engine, begins to tinker with it for a mom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: steering. She is calm, resolute. Allnutt comes back into  SHOT. His brows are working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This 'ere storm is messing things up  a bit. 'Er bows 'ave got to ride  'igh or we'll be swamped before we  get 'alf way to The Louisa. On the  other 'and, they've got to be low  when we 'it 'er, so' the explosion  will be down at 'er waterline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can anything be done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Just before we 'it, I'll bring the  ballast back forrard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, sweetheart darling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wave breaks over the side, drenching them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blimey!

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: It rolls extravagantly as a wind of incredible speed whip down on the lake and rouses the shallow waters to maniaca fury. A series of waves come crashing against the flat si Then suddenly the darkness is torn away by a dazzling fla of lightning which reveals the wild waters around them.  Thunder follows with a loud BANG like a thousand cannon f at once. Then comes the rain pouring down through the  blackness in solid rivers. The wind abates momentarily, but the surface of the lake  still heaves. The boat begins to pound, raising her bows  high out of the water and bringing them down again with a shattering CRASH. Allnutt seizes a pail and begins to bail furiously, but t no purpose. Now the wind strikes from a new quarter, laying its grip the torn surface of the lake and building it up into  mountains.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: numbed and stupefied, but struggling to maintain her hold the tiller. Suddenly Allnutt is at her side, putting her through a life buoy. They totter and sway for a long mome then the stern of the launch is engulfed by a heavy wave, and they are up to their waists in water. The African Que is swamped. Very slowly she capsizes. In the distance we the lights of The Louisa, safe at anchor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAPTAIN and FOUR of the SHIP'S OFFICERS constitute th court in a proceeding against a small man dressed in woma bloomers and a ragged singlet. The latter stands, chin on his chest, gazing dully at the carpet. The CAPTAIN is President of the court, of course. He is a corpulent man with whiskers, groomed in imitation of von  Triplitz. Behind him on the wall is a portrait in oils of the Kaiser. He keeps his eyes closed throughout the  proceedings. To the Captain's right, stands the ship's FIRST OFFICER, is acting as prosecutor. He is clean-shaven, dark, with p blue eyes; his manner is rigidly correct. To the Captain' left, sits the ship's SECOND OFFICER, who is serving as  defense counsel. He is a sleepy, stupid looking man with big scar on his cheek. All three members of the court are snowy ducks with gold buttons, white gloves and decoratio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in broken English) What is your nationality?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt does nothing to indicate he hears the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French?... Belgian?... English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thickly) English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing on the island? (Allnutt remains  sullenly silent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The punishment for not answering the court is hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. 'Ang me. 'Oo cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing on the island?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know that you are in an area  prohibited to all but members of the  forces of His Imperial Majesty, Kaiser  Wilhelm II?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Oo cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your rank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ow's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a soldier, are you not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) Naaa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) The prisoner is obviously here to  spy on the movements of the K?nigin  Luise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain, without opening his eyes, turns to the Secon Officer; nods to him to proceed. The latter is completely a loss. He rises, stammers a few words in German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) No proof of criminal intent --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, tongue-tied; then throws up his hands in a fina gesture, sits heavily and starts wiping his face with a  handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Allnutt in English) What were you doing here, if you  were not spying? (Allnutt doesn't answer) The Court sentences you to death by  hanging. (then in German to  the others) Not from the yard arm, but when we  reach port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment, there is a bustle outside the tiny crowde cabin. Then the door opens and a colored Petty Officer co in and salutes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Swahili) We are about to pick up another one.  A woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain rises and goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: FROM HIS VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: She is sitting on one of the small barren islands, a litt way up from the beach; the dinghy manned by native oarsme with a white officer, is already half way there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) She looks like she's white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Allnutt in English) Was there a woman with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt drops his mask of sullen stupidity and turns quic to the door, but the Captain's bulk is blocking his view. tries to push him aside. The First Officer hits Allnutt a hard blow across the face. Allnutt runs to a porthole and looks out in time to see:

dialogues.speaker: ROSE FROM HIS POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: She is struggling with the WHITE OFFICER who is trying to make her enter the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: frantic with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls, shouting) Rosie! Rosie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back) Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The First Officer, who seems to enjoy hitting Allnutt, no delivers a second blow, this time knocking him down. He  remains standing over Allnutt while the Captain and Secon Officer resume their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Allnutt) Who is that woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising unsteadily) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you just called her by name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) Maybe I'll change my mind and hang  you from the yard arm after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o.s., the SOUND of approaching steps; then Rose, followed the WHITE OFFICER, enters the cabin. She stands staring a Allnutt for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie dear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ello, Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha! You do know her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I calls all the girls Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WHITE OFFICER swings into view a life buoy on which i printed "The African Queen".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) She had this with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rose, in English) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Rose Sayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing on the lake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't told 'im nothin', Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer the question!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were boating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night? In such weather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were not responsible for the  weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why were you boating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is our affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As your fellow-prisoner has already  learned, the penalty for not answering  the court is death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slow take) You mean he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets it. She goes swiftly close to Allnutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie! Are they telling me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) Order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The First Officer lays a restraining hand on her shoulder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheeling in fury and  slapping him hard  across the face) Stop that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes cold and smiles yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they, Charlie? The truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allnutt looks back at her; his chin begins to tremble; wi heroic effort he masters it. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fraulein Sayer, you will come to  order and answer the questions of  this court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose wheels and faces him; she is all cold fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask your questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing on the lake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We came here to sink this ship, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a loud voice) Rosie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and we would have, too, except  for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's at least have the fun of telling  them about it, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you believe her, yer Honor.  She's touched with the fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Oh stop it, Charlie, we've been  through all this. (primly) I'm not going to outlive you and  that's all there is to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit amused and  skeptical) Just how, Fraulein, did you propose  to sink -- the K?nigin Luise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were going to ram you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With how large a vessel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With torpedoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (look at each other;  in unison) Torpedoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torpedoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison; tossing  bones to a dog; in  German) Torpedoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaping) Nein! (foolish enough to  believe Rose and  Allnutt, he looks at  them with awe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interpreting, smooth  and sardonic) I think it is safe to assume, Miss  Sayer, that the British Admiralty  did not entrust you and this --  gentleman -- with the torpedoes.  Will you be so good as to tell us  precisely where and how you acquired  them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acquired? Mr. Allnutt made them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First Officer and Captain exchange a significant glance: is obviously nuts. (All through this, the Second Officer, who no spik English, is like a puzzled observer at a tenn match.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little like a warden  in a loony house) How very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you even believe me.  Tell him how you did it, Charlie. (Over Allnutt's lines,  the officers exchange  glances which mean:  "He's loony, too".)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (100% the engineer) Well -- wot I did was take the 'eads  off two cylinders of oxygen an' fill  'em up with 'igh explosive -- 'bout  two 'undred weight. That was easy  enough -- it was the detonators took  some hingenooity. Know wot I used?  Cartridges, an' nails, in blocks o'  soft wood. A pretty job. Then I  mounted the cylinders so they stuck  through the bows of The African Queen,  near the water line, so when we rammed  you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half believing what  he can't believe) Where is The African Queen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sank in the storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get onto the lake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We came down the Ulanga -- the Bora,  you call it down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All three officers look at each other -- even the Second  Officer catches this -- and back at Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) (together) But that is impossible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevertheless!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody knows the river is  unnavigable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) We came down it, though -- didn't  we, Charlie? -- on The African Queen.

dialogues.speaker: THE DERELICT AFRICAN QUEEN
dialogues.text: floating keel up. She is under water except for the two  cylinders which stick up like the antennae of a snail. CAMERA DOES LONG PULL BACK, to show The Louisa approachin

dialogues.speaker: ROSE AND ALLNUTT
dialogues.text: as they come out of the cabin surrounded by the ship's  officers. The company stops near the main mast where a cr member has finished making a hangman's noose of one rope is now tying a knot in another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Captain) The man first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- hang us together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods to the First Officer to proceed with the executio Allnutt and Rose exchange a look of satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie, I ain't gonna say goodbye  again. It's gettin' to be an old  story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next moment, the deck heaves upward. There is a rush air and a frightful ROAR. Smoke and flying debris fill th SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: THE WATER
dialogues.text: where those who were on deck are now struggling. There is something ludicrous about the Germans in their ducks with the gold buttons and decorations trying to keep above wat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wot 'appened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did it, Charlie, we did it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But 'ow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose points to a piece of wreckage floating on the water the near distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'll be... Are you all right,  Rosie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never better. And you, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bit of all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all turned round, Charlie. Which  way is the south shore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one we're swimming towards, old  girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES TOWARD the piece of wreckage, losing Rose an Allnutt, into CLOSE SHOT showing the printed words "Afric Queen" on the wreckage. When the name fills the SCREEN --
